div.p: BELLAMIRA, OR THE MISTRESS, A Comedy: As it is Acted by Their Majesties Servants.
Written by the Honourable Sir CHARLES SEDLEY Baronet.
LONDON: Printed by D. Mallet, for L. C. and Timothy Goodwin, at the Maiden-Head over against St. Dunstans Church in Fleet-Street. 1687.

div.head: The PREFACE TO THE READER.
div.p:
I Know very well the danger of Writing in such an age where the best Wits Chose rather to be lookerson, then expose their stock of reputation to Publick censure. Nor did I design any to my self by this Play: It was originally Maenanders in the Greek, Terence's in the Latin; whose great names gave me a Curiosity to try how I cou'd make it run in English: A Friend came to my Chamber as I was upon the first Act, he seem'd to approve my design: I told him I found it extream easie to go through with: And that if he cou'd get it Acted under his own or anothers Name, I wou'd finish it for him: But for I know not what reasons he cou'd not do it; and I was oblidg'd to own it my self, or my friend had lost his third day The whole Play runs upon a Rape committed by a Lover under the disguise of an Eunuch, and an indulgent Keeper, govern'd and Jilted by his Imperious Mistress, which parts were so essential that they cou'd
not be omitted, nor well fitted to our Stage without some expressions or Metaphors, which by persons of a ticklish imagination, or over-quick sense that way, seem'd too lascivious for modest Ears; I confess after the Plays I have seen lately Crowded by that fair Sex: the exception did not a little surprise me; And this suddain change of theirs made me call to mind our English weather, where in the same day a man shall Sweat in Crape, and wish for a Campagn Coat three hours after. I am very unhappy that the Ice that has borne so many Coaches and Carts, shou'd break with my Wheel barrow: I confess to have taken my Idea of Poetry more from the Latin than the French: and had rather be accus'd of some Irregularities, than tire my Reader or Audience with a smooth even stream of insipid words and accidents; such as one can neither like nor find fault with. But Reader between what will not please, and what will not pass at this time; there is so little left to be said on this or any other Subject, that I will keep thee no longer at the Door. Go in and Judge for thy self, see what the Modesty of this year takes offence at, and I am confident thou wilt with me congratulate the happy change. And yet absolve both the Poet and the Translator from any unpresidented indecency.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: IS it not strange to see in such an Age
The Pulpit get the better of the Stage?
Not through Rebellion as in former days,
But Zeal for Sermons and neglect for Plays.
Here's as good Ogling vet, and fewer spies.
For Godly Parents watch with whites of Eyes.
Here Gallants do but pay us for your Room,
Bring if you please, your own brisk wit from home.
Proclaim your drunken fray's three benches round
What Claps y'have met with, and what puuks are sound
Who are the Bully-rocks: and who gives ground.
We take all in good part, and never rage:
Tho the shrill Pit be louder than the Stage.
There you must sit demure, without a word:
Nor Perruque comb'd, nor Pocket tortoise stir'd
Here you may give the Lye, or draw your Sword.
Be low'd and sensless, huff, dumbfound, and roar;
Till all the Lady's and some gallants scowre.
What free born subject, or true English heart,
Wou'd with such Rights and Priviledges part?
When our two houses did divide the Town,
Each Faction zealously maintain'd their own,
We liv'd on those that came to cry us down.
Our Emulation did improve your sport:
Now you come hither but to make your Court:
Or from adjacent Coffee Houses throng
At our sourth Act for a new Dance or Song.
To set all right we yet could make a shift;
Had we a few good Livings in our gift.
Your hearts are ours, and let whoever preach
The young and fair will practice what we teach.
Our Play old virtuous Rome the Eunuch nam'd
But modest London the lewd title damn'd.
Our Author try'd his own and cou'd not hit:
He now presents you with some Forraign Wit.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: Mixt Essays upon Tragedies, Comedies, Italian Comedies, English Comedies, and Opera's to his Grace the Duke of Buckingham. Written Originally in French by the Sieur de Saint EUREMONT.
Printed for Timothy Goodwin, at the Maiden-Head over against St. Dunstans Church in Fleetstreet, 1687.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: I Ever told you, this Woman wou'd be the ruine of you: all must go to make her fine, and every New Gown you give, gets you a new Rival.

sp.speaker: Keepw.
sp.p: Thou thinkst all Mony thrown away, that is not spent in a Tavern: thou hast no tast of Love, scarce any remains of Lust, or thou would'st never Rail at so Divine a Creature as my Bellamira.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: You are resolved to go to her again; notwithstanding the damn'd trick she serv'd you with the Sea Captain and your noble resolution to the contrary? I'll see her hang'd first! No, tho she beg it a thousand times, and with a thousand tears, I'll n'e'r go near her!

sp.speaker: Keepw.
sp.p: Did I say such bug-words?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Yes, and a great deal more.

sp.speaker: Keepw.
sp.p: 'Twas when I was in my Altitudes, what? Rebell against my Lawful Sovereign Bellamira! I'll go to her tho, and shew her I am not such a Cully as she takes me for.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Have a care what you do: If you once begin and don't go through with her, you settle her Empire for ever; and when she finds her own strength, that you are not able to leave her, she will use it like a Tyrant: And tho you be the injur'd party, after six kind words and a false tear or two, you must make your peace with a Present of China or a French Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: These are sad Truths; but when my Bell. frowns I had rather be in a Sea-Fight for the time, I'll say that for her, tho 'tis soon over. I gave her but a dozen pair of Marshal Gloves, and she was in the purest Humour all day! We took the Air in the afternoon, Sup't and went to Bed together.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: That was a gawdy day indeed, but I fear you'l give so long, till you have nothing left.

sp.speaker: Keepw.
sp.p: I had rather give a little Mony, than Lye, Flatter and Forswear my self as the Gallants of the Town do: I love to go to Sleep with a good Conscience.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: And rise with ne'r a Penny in your Pocket; if she lov'd you she would not be so expensive.

sp.speaker: Keepw.
sp.p: 'Tis all to please me. Before I knew her she wore a Gown six months; and had but one poor Point of her own making.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Matters are well mended with her indeed since that time.

sp.speaker: Keepw.
sp.p: I had the most to do to make her accept of an Imbroider'd Toylet.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Keepw.
sp.p: She said 'twas Mony thrown away.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: And wou'd have it in Guineas, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Keepw.
sp.p: Thou art a Witch, she cares not a Farthing for Fine Cloaths; and but for fear the Women of the Town shou'd get me from her, wou'd not dress her self in a Month.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: You are too indulgent a Keeper: the poor Sinners of the Town complain of you; you raise the Market upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Keepw.
sp.p: Why what wou'd a man do?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Let one Nail drive out another: Take me a fresh Wench, a Bottle of Wine or two, and go hear some Scandal at the Roseâ€” But here she comes, who with one Look will confound all our Devices.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Keepwell! I am afraid thou art Jealous of me, because I did not let thee in sooner; the news of it put me into such Fits, all our Maids were too few to hold me.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: The news of what?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Of a Duel I was told thou hadst fought: there was no body to run to the Door; but thou saw'st there was no man with me.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I saw no man indeed, but am much mistaken if I did not hear one leap out of your low Window into a Boat.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: This Summer one or other is leaping into the River all night long.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Oh, that you lov'd like me; or I like you!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why my dear Keepwell?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Why, then you'd never use me thus, or if you did, it wou'd not thus afflict me: my heart is as full of Jealousie as an Egg full of meat.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I swear by all thats good there is no man on Earth so welcome to these Arms, as thy dear self.

sp.speaker: Keepw.
sp.p: Why did not you let me in sooner then?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I was just rising out of a Bath, and I will be seen haked by no man Living.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Kind Soul! first she was in Fits for fear you were hurt; but now she was coming out of a Bath, and cou'd not in modesty let you in.

sp.speaker: Keepw.
sp.p: She fell into Fits just as she came out of her Bath.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I have alwaies your good word: But I had rather you shou'd say any thing of me, than kill my dear Keepwell with Drinking. But now I'll tell you the business I came about: Can your Drunken Friend keep a Secret?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: If it be a Truth; but it prove a Lye, a Flam, a Wheadle, 'twill out: I shall tell it the next man I meet.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Father was a Merchant, and Breaking here in Town, my Mother went to Jamaica, and took me with her.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: This may be kept secret.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: There a Person of Quality fell in Love with her, and amongst other Presents, gave her the finest Girl I ever saw, stoln out of England by some Kidnappers.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Rogues that make a Trade of Stealing Children and Selling them.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Was she a Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She said so, and she seem'd so.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Not so pretty as thou art I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Her Father and Mother were Dead; her Brothers name she told us; my Mother bred her as if she had been her own Child, so that most people thought us Sisters; I came back with a Friend, the only Person I had then a Concern with, who gave me all I have.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: These are two Whiskers!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Because you were never true to one Man: nor did he give you all you have; my Friend here having presented you with two thousand Pound at least.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Will you let me go on with my Story? My Mother left this pretty Creature Isabella almost grown a Woman, to an Uncle of mine, for some Mony that she ow'd him, and cou'd not otherwise pay: He thinking she might yeild a good Price, carries her over into Spain, and there Sells her to one Dangerfield, who buys her and puts her to wait on his Sister: he is now in England, and offers her me.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Did he know that she was formerly your Companion?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not in the least; but since hearing of my concern with you, he seeks all the excuses he can, not to perform his Promise; and says that he knows as soon as I have, her he shall be slighted, and you received; for he has heard how dearly I Love thee.

sp.speaker: Keepw.
sp.p: All the Town knows there is no Love lost. Is this all?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, I have a small request to thee my Dear.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Now for a Coach, new Bed, or the Payment of an old Debt.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You are mistaken Sir; cou'd I help it I wou'd not put my dear Keepwell to the Charge of one of your Drunken Clubs in a Year.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: You spend it him in Coach-hire, Puppy-water and Paint, every day of your Life.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Peace, thou moving Dropsie, that wadlest with Fat, worse than a Goose with Egg

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: No man that had to do with you, e're lost his Shape; Fluxing and Sweating are great Preservatives.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p:
This is rudeness and not Wit; come thou art my best Companion and she my dearest Mistriss. As our modern Poet has it;
If not in Friendship, live at least in Peace.
What is it thou woud'st Command?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Command! only a trifling Suit I have.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: It must be a strange one if I refuse it; Is it in my power?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Then speak and be sure to obtain it, as if thou ask'dst it of thy self. I have not given thee any thing all this day.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis no Mony matter: there are many Reasons why I wou'd have this Isabella from Dangerfield: First because we were bred together, like Sisters, and of all the World I love her next thy dear self; and if I cou'd restore her to her Friends, who I hear are very considerable, I doubt not of a good Reward: so that I shall never need trouble thee for any thing more.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: This is a good Wheadle.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: But how will you get her? You say Dangerfield repents him of his promise.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis but thy going into the Country for a day or two, and I shall easily perswade that swaggering Fool out of her. You don't answer me.

sp.speaker: Keep
sp.p: What shou'd I answer thee, thou worst of Women?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: She wou'd only lie with this roaring Rascal a Night or two, while you are in the Countrie: can you have the heart to deny her?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: If I deny her, she'l be outragious; and if I do not, I shall have Elks horns at my return. I understand you Isabella; and you were bred up like Sisters, you wou'd restore her to her Friends, and so Dangerfield must be received, and I banish'd; and why? but that you love him better than ever you did me, and are affraid this Young Wench should get the Lusty Stallion from you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She loves me so, she wou'd not be my Rival, tho' in thee, young, kind, and handsome as thou art.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Is this Souldier then the only Man that made a considerable Present? When has my Bounty fail'd? Didnot you ask the other Day a Blackamoor, and then an Eunuch, out of a meer Humour, because Princes use 'em, and straight I pawn'd a Ring to buy 'em for you? I should not urge my Bounty, did I not find that you forget it. There was a Settlement drawing too.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay, rather than you shall take it ill, I will Renounce this Isabella, the dear Companion of my Youth, for ever, and all the World beside.

sp.speaker: Keep
sp.p: Did not you say you cou'd renounce this Isabella, and all the World for me?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Yes, rather than lose your Settlement.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I did; and will, my Dear! I can go into a Cloyster, since I have lost my power with you, I care not for the rest, I'll to a Monastery, and there I'll Pray for you.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I scorn to be out-done in Kindness: I will go into the Country for a day or two, and let Dangerfield do his worst. Go into a Monastery! I had rather hold the Door my self.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: When she's a Nun I'll be a Fryer: They all say as much.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: But, if she shou'd, where shou'd I have such another Dear, Pretty, Sweet Rogue?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: There are hundreds as fine Women to be had, by the day, by the week, or how you will.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: 'Tis not the first time she has threatned to go into a Monastery, upon discontents between us: I was forced to give her a New Bed, the last Summer, and Plate for her Chamber, or I had lost her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis but two days, and I am thine for ever.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Hang two days among Friends.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis I shall be the greatest Sufferer, who must endure the Man I loath, and part with him I love. Besides, this Dangerfield is such a troublesome quarrelsome Fellow, I shou'd never have one Minutes quiet, if you were in Town together, for fear of some mischief or other.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Nay, there wou'd be Bloud-shed every hour, that's certain; I ne-never cou'd endure a Rival in my Life.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I know thou art both brave and jealous, that makes me so affraid for thee: If he shou'd Kill thee, poor Dear, he has nothing to lose, and wou'd easily get his Pardon; but should'st thou Kill him, all the world can't save thee, thou hast been such a Whig. Besides, I am too honest a Woman to have any interest at Court.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: It shall never come to that, I'le away into the Country, and as it happens have a little business there; I shall come up so vigorous, and so Loving; wee'l have a Sack-Posset, and go to Bod together, tho' it be at Noon-day: But see, my Friend, the Black a more and Eunuch be deliver'd to Bellamira in my absence.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: I will carry them my self, and try what Mettle Bellamira is made of in his absence: she is the prettiest Wench in the Town, and his Present will make me welcome.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: For two long Days and todious Nights, Farewel.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I fear my Keepwell, thou think'st me one of those little Creatures of the Town; but I have told thee nothing but the Truth: nor is there Man on Earth I wou'd prefer to thee. All I do, is meerly in compassion to pretty Isabella, in hope to restore her to her Brother, whom by some Tokens she gave me, I think I have found, and am this Night to Treat with.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Farewel, my dearest Bellamira, I am gone.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, now I see thou dost deserve my Love.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Yonder's Merryman, Fat, Smooth, and looks Young still; a very Bacchus incarnate.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: I swallow more Wine, than Pills or Dyet-drink, sit up till Three, and drink my three Bottles.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I met the pretty'st Creature in New Spring-Garden! her Gloves right Marshal, her Petticoat of the New Rich Indian Stuffs, her Fan Colambor: Angel-water was the worst Sent about her.
I am sure she was of Quality.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: And I warrant, you think she came to meet you there?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Not so: She came to take her Fortune among the Young Fellows of the Town, and Chance threw her upon me; I have found she lies in the Mall.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: There are Whores of all sorts; but if she had lain in an Alley, you might have more hope of her.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Have not you the best Wine and Tobacco, where you com

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Yes, that I have.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Why then shou'd you not think, a Man that makes it his business, as I do, may have the finest Women?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: I pay 'em well, and get custom to Taverns where I go; a Wench may starve that has had to do with you; no Man will venture upon her, who has any Reverence for his Nose: Nor have you any thing to give 'em but the Pox.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: You can do as little to a Woman as I can give: And for your soundness, if Palsie, Gout, and Dropsie may be called so, your drunken impotence is the reason of it.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Will this Quarrel never be at end? Cuningham is the Darling of the Ladies, and Merriman the delight of all good Fellows. Whats become of our Old Friend Keepwel?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: We have lost him: He was once an honest well humor'd Fellow, tho' he had never much Wit, but since his Acquaintance with Bellamira.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: What, she that was so well known at Jamaica?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: That's true, but he won't believe it: She has perswaded him 'twas an Elder Sister's she is handsomer, and he more in Love with her than ever. You know how miserable he was.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: He always grudg'd his Club, if it came to above half a Crown.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: How plain he went?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: He bought all his Cloaths of a Whole sale Man.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Now there's no Taylor curious enough for him.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: 'Tis a great change, but I cannot blame him; she is a delicate Creature, and I was one of the first that Debauch'd her.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: I thought you wou'd not have confess'd so much Age.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I mean I was one of the first had her, after she came over: she Lov'd me dearly, poor Rogue, but I was not able to maintain her.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: One man may as well satisfie, as maintain her; she is the most expensive Jade I ever knew; she has run Keepwell a thousand Pound in Debt within this Twelve month: I have been at a woful parting between them.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: He has not turn'd her off I hope? For I go and Sup there sometimes, upon the old account. She is one of my Piz Allez.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: No; she has turn'd him off for two days: he has left an Eunuch in Town, which I am to present her for him anon.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I'le tell you a Secret; I had like to have been surprized there by Keepwell himselfe'ne now; we were just got to Bed together.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: And how got you off?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: She made him Knock half an hour at the Door, whil'st I leapt out of one of her lower Windows into a Boat that waited for me But Morriman, you must say nothing upon honour, now you are trusted.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Not I, I have told him of thy lying with her and Forty others, an hundred times, and he will never believe me; he is the most incorrigible Cully, I begin to be of her side.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I will drink a Bottle more with thee at Night for that: A Man of honour shou'd always take the Ladies parts.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: What made you run away? I thought you had been allowed to visit.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I am so, but not in my Shirt and Night-Gown, as I was with her. She was just out of a Bath, the Sweetest, Whitest, Plumpest, Kindest Rogue.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: 'Twas a Damn'd disappointment.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Not quite, I took my leave of her like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: I wonder Keepwell continues sound, coming after thee in this manner.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: There was a Plague in Sixty Six, but what is that to London now? there was a Fire too: but it is since new Built, and more beautiful than ever; are not you Sober now, tho' you were Drunk last Night?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Not quite.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: A Dish of Coffee or two will make you so, and do you think there's no Redemption in other Cases?

When they were first acquainted, I Writ all his Billet doux for him, for Keepwell you know has nothing but the Purse and Dotage of a good Lover; he wou'd give me now and then five Guineas for a Song for her, which Ilet her know was mine; when I saw her next, we Laught at the poor Fool together.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: I'le say that for him, he is fitted with a Friend and a Mistress.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: You know he is but a dull silly Fellow.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: And therefore you may very honestly pretend Friendship, borrow his Money and lye with his Mistress.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p:
A Pious Citizen that goes to Church twice a day, will play the Knave in a Bargain; a Lawyer take your Fee, and for a good Sum of Mony, be absent when your Cause is try'd; a Parson Marry you to a great
Fortune without a Licence; We are all Regues in our way, and I confess Woman is my weak side; And yonder goes an odd Fellow, with a very pretty Wench: what a Toss she has with her head, and a jett with her breech?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: 'Slight, 'tis Smoothly, Dangerfield's man, carrying that pretty Creature to Bellamira, for a Present from his Master.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: She has as good a Face as Bellamira her self.
sp.stage: Eustace's Man brings him a Note.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Smallwit, Wildman, and Lyonel, have sent their excuses, and cannot Dine.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Let's give the House something, and Dine there to Morrow: I am invited to a Vension-Pasty, and a dozen-bottles among Four.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I have some Ladies to Entertain at Knightsbridge; and hate a nasty Tavern.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Since you are all provided for, I'le shift, for my self.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He's gon, and we are free as Mountain Air.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: You have absolute Dominion over him; but to make him accessary to his own disgrace, was such a Masterpiece!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now will he entertain a better opinion of me than ever: he'le think I do nothing without his consent, since I once ask'd him it, and in so nice a Point.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: What said Merryman, my sweet Guardian?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: All he cou'd, you must take him off for me.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: I am but his second Inclination; a Drawer in a good Tavern has more Interest in him, than I.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But Keepwell is the Loyalest Cully! nothing will make him Mutiny.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Sure you think he can read in no Book but his own, or you durst never use him so.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: There are few of those Clerks now-adays: this is a Learned Age. When saw you Cuningham?

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: He comes sometimes and professes his Love and Soundness to me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Believe him in neither, they say he's a false Fellow.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Theard he was formerly a great Servant of yours.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What a Lying World this is! I never saw him in my Life.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: That's strange and live about this Town.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Is he handsome? Black? or Fair?

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Between both.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Has he much Wit?

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: As if you did not know!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I swear, not I.

sp.speaker: This
sp.p: Jilting Devil! I'd not know him so well for a Thousand Pound: but 'tis the Trick of most of 'em; tho they own Twenty, they will forswear some one.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh, that I had thy Youth, and Beauty!

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: You have enough of both, considering your Judgment and Experience.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We Women are easiliest deceived, when we are most worth it: Cunning and Wrinkles come together.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: You have no reason to complain; all the young Fellows that come out of France, pay Tribute to you, as certainly as to the Groom-Porter: I wonder Keepwell is never told of it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He has been told it a hundred times: Two or three Stories that the Authors have not been able to make out, have don me great Service; and so confirm'd my Empire.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: But you are in continual fear.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I have broke him of all his Censorious Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: That was a great Point gain'd; but how?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I tell him such a one will Cheat him, another will bring him into Quarrels, a third speaks ill of him behind his Back, a fourth is obnoxious to the great ones, and will hinder his Preferment: So that I have scarce left him one Friend that will tell him a true word.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: You are a great Politician.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: There goes more to our Trade, than a good Face: I have known many of these unthinking Butterflyes, Debauch'd, Pox'd, and in Goal, the same Summer: Let's up into my Chamber; I must set my self out for Dangerfield he'l be here anon.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Will you use the Paint was sent in by the French Woman this Morning?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: By all means: Lying and Painting are sure Baits to Catch a Fool with.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: What sort of Fellow is that Dangerfield?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Beau Garcon of Fifty, with a Blew Chin, stiff Beard, and soforth.â€” Loves the Old Fashion'd Greasy way of giving Treats, will Dance Country Dances till he Sweat like a Running Foot-man; tires himself first, and then makes Love.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: They say he has been Hansome.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
'Twas so long ago every Body has forgot it, but himself: He is a
pretender to Wit; but his is worse than none: as a Country Scraper is worse than no Musick at all,

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: And yet this Fellow for a little Mony,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, for a great deal of Mony. I will make the Presents he gives me, my Baits to Catch others with: fine, Cloaths and rich Furniture, are great Provocatives to those that don't pay for'em, which are the Men for our Turn.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Like the Gentlemen that live in Town, you have your pleasure in one place, and receive your Rent from an other: 'tis the way to have your I enement thrown into your Hands.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Keepwell has taken a Lease for Life, and laid out so much in Improvemtnts, that I am secure of him; and for the rest, they shall pay me as they are Able.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: My Guardian and I have now and then a small Quarrel, about my keeping you so much Company.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What, Merryman? I thought he had made Love to you.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: He dos sometimes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He has then forfeited his Charter and ought to Talk no more like a Guardian.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Perhaps he dos not like it as a Lover.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Does he not see that we Govern the Town? have Power and Plenty follow us? we Visit, Dance, Play at Cards, go to Hide-Park, St. James's, and Sup together, and are a World among our Selves.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: But like the Inhabitants of the other World, you neither Marry, nor are given in Marrige; and he wou'd have me fit for a Husband.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Get Mony enough and you can never want a Husband. A Husband is a good Bit to Close ones Stomach with, when Love's Feast is over. Who wou'd begin a Meal with Cheese? Come into my Chamber, and I will instruct thee farther in these Mysteries.

div.head: ACT II. SCENE I

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: WHAT, not gon yet? hovering like a Ghost, about your Treasure?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I stay'd to see how my Presents took: you have deliver'd 'em, I hope, what says my Bellamira?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: The Meat's hardly out of my Mouth, and I am for no Exercise upon a full Stomach: 'tis too far to walk yet.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Take a Coach,

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: That's as bad as the Rack, to a Man of my Intemperate, and Voracious Appetite: I am so full I should spill Terso at every jolt. We drank Gallons a piece.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: You are Drunk then.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: No, Sober enough to be your Worship's Pimp, and diliver your Humane Gelding to Bellamira.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: But will you go about it Instantly, and make hast?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Survey my Bulk: it was not built for hast;
'Tis the slow product of Tuns of Claret, Chines of Beef, Ven'son-Pastyes, and so-forth.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Now you are in this humor, you will talk some Wit to her and spoil all.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: I'le be there, before you are half a Mile out of Town, and say the sweetest things of you!

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Thou think'st I cannot leave my Bellamira, now it comes to the Point.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: I am somwhat doubtful.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Yes if it were for three days, now I am resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: What, a whole three days! Thou hast a Heart of Iron.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Cou'd you be Sober so long?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Yes to save the Nation, or so.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Nothing less serve the turn?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Yes or to oblige Mrs. Thisbe, my Charge.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Thou hast always Wine and Women in thy Head together: a sure sign thou are but an indifferent Tilterâ€” Well, I am in hast, be sure you go, and omit nothing that may endear my small Present to her.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: He's gon; but here comes our Rival's Servant, with that Beautyful young Creature, again: It seems Bellamira was not at home. I'le step aside and observe her.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: There is as much difference between Man and Man, as between Man and Beast: This Fool my Master gives away this pretty young Creature, to a stale Wench, I am but a Servant, and must obey; but were I to chuse.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Peace, Impudence; were I to chuse, I'de chuse a Halter before either of you.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: I was not always thus a Servant, as you see me, I am a Gentleman, and once had an Estate, but now 'tis gon, must live on others, as others did on me.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Perhaps so.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: I now am fain to Lye, and Flatter for my Bread, shift for my Cloaths, and humor every Idle Coxcomb to get a Piece or two: Does my Patron lose? Fortune favours Fools: Does he Win? sweet is his hand, and happy are his Servants. Is he Dwarfish? his Strength is the more compact: Is he Tall? such the first Monarch's were, when Kingdoms went by Choice: Is he Ugly, and Witty which must ever be? such Ovid was, whom Julia so priz'd: Is he Hansom? such was Adonis, whom fair Venus Lov'd.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: And were you never Cudgel'd, for this nauseous Flattery?

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: There are a sort of Men who think themselves the first in all kinds, and are the last; these I get acquainted with: nor do I attempt to please'em with my Wit, but win their hearts an easier way, by Applauding theirs If any of'em tell an old Tale, that I have Read in Print, straight I never heard any thing so well, and listen to it as if it were my Fathers last Will and Testament. Does he offer at a Jest? I dye with Laughing, before his Mouth opens. Does he walk Home, without taking Cold? he is hardy and fit to be a General.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You are a fine Rogue all this while! And what else?

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: In short, I say as they say, deny what they deny, like what they like, and if they dispraise it again, I am ready to do so too; and find my account very well in it; while those Fops, that are fond of shewing their own Wit, are hated by all my Customers; who are the onely Men there's any thing to be gotten by.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: This is a notable Fellow; and if he finds Men Fools, is enough to make'em Mad.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Were I a Man, I had rather dye than sell my words, and prostitute my Voice to every Fool.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: Don't Lawyers, Physitians, and Courtiers, when they take Mony for a good Turn, sell their words? There was a blunt Comrade of mine of your mind; but I found him the other day all in Rags, not a Peny in his Pocket, nor a Friend to help him: I have nothing, and yet want nothing; strong and able; other Mens Meat, and Drink, and Wives serve my Turn.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Leave your Prating, and move forward.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: Sure you are some disguis'd Princess, you take upon you so.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: What I am I know not, and am only sure I am miserable.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: What's here my Rivals Friend Merryman, before Bellanair's Door? I knew him when I was last in Town. Your most Humble Servant Worthy Sir.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Yours, honest Smoothly.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: Will you not go in?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: I have no business at present.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: You may be welcome, for your Friend Keepwell's sake.
Do you see nothing here you wou'd not see?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Nothing but thy self.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: You keep your old blunt way; but, look you what here is! Look you what here is! What will not Bellamira do for such a Bribe?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Every Dog has his day:

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: Let me not keep you here, you were going some where else.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: Pray then, will you Introduce me to Madam Bellamira?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: You need not fear admittance, with such a Present.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: But perhaps you stand here, to see that no man brings any Message from Dangerfield.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: You are pleasant! but if I did I'de Cudgel you farther off.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: He is Angry, and the Fat Fool is Stout: I'le not provoke him.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Yonder's Lionel, Keepwell's younger Brother, he comes in hast, and seem's to have somthing in his Head.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: I am undone! ruin'd! I have lost the sight of this Pretty Creature, and shall never find her more! which way shall I go? whom shall I enquire of? what shall I do, to have a Glimps of her? I have only this comfort; where e're she is, she is too Beautiful to be long Conceal'd. From henceforth, I blot all former Faces out of my heart: I am tir'd with these daily Beauties of the Town, whom we see Painted and Pateh'd in the Afternoon in the Play house, in the Evening at the Park, and at Night in the Drawing room; so that we have half enjoy'd 'em before we speak to'em

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p:
Lost! Undone! Beautiful! I am sure I heard these words plain: he is in Love, and after the manner of that sort of Madmen is talking to himself, of his Mistress; If he be we shall have fine work; there are Ten Keepwells in that Lionel: he'l commit Rapes, Burglaries, Fire houses, or any thing, but he'l have her; and for Mony, he'l throw it a way like Dirt.
I pity his poor Father; but he Grudg'd his Mony for honest Terse, and so he's right enough serv'd.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Eternal Palsies on that Cuningham's Hands, may he never be able to put his Dice into the Box; but when he does may he throw out for ever. May he Win of Beggars and lose to Bullies, and dote on Whores as Rotten as himself. But I was mad to mind him: how I envy yon' Merryman, whose sluggish Blood moves in an even stream, and never knows these Storms!

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: What's the matter? you look as if you were Drunk.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: I am worse; I am mad; I am any thing; I am in Love.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: How Keepwell will Laugh at you! But with whom?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Not with a stale Wench, like him; nor any of the little Tinsel, short Liv'd Beauties of the Town, squeez'd into shape by Taylors, and starv'd into it by their Mothers.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: How then?

sp.speaker: Lion
sp.p: A new turn of a Face, unknown till now to Nature's self, in all her Numberless Varieties.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: 'Tis wond'erous; you are Maul'd; Cupid has shot you with a Blunderbus.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: What Eyes! Teeth, whiteâ€”

sp.speaker: Merry
sp.p: As a new Tobacco-pipe

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Peace Prophane Wretch, thou art not fit to mingle in these Misteries. Her own Complexion; her Body solid and full of Juice; the Noblest Fabrick of unstinted Nature!

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Her Age?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Seventeen.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: I have drunk excellent Hockamore of that Age.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Damn thy dull Hockamore and thy base Jaded Pallat, that affects it; Cou'd I but get this Divine Creature into my hands, by Fraud, Force, Price, Prayer, any way so that I enjoy her, I care not.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Who is she? she may be a Person of Quality, and you may bring an old house upon your head

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: 'Tis but a Duel or two that way; and if her Relations be Numerous, we'l Fight Six to Six, and make an end on't.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: What Country Woman is she?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Where does she live?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: I can't tell,

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: We are upon a very cold Scent: where did you see her?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: In the Street; with a Servant behind her.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: How come you to lose her?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: That's it I was Cursing at, as I met you: Nor do I think there is a Man whom all the Stars conspire against like me. What Crime have I committed, to be thus Plagu'd?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: The Stars are Pretty Twinkling Rogues, that light us home, when we are Drunk sometimes, but neither care for you, nor me, nor any man.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: You know Cuningham?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Intimately: a good honest Fellow; a little too much a Servant to the Ladies, given to Gaming.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Pox of his Character!

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: The Pox is part of his Character indeed, but I had forgot that.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Will you not let me go on with my Story? This Fellow meets me in the nick of time, while I was following this Divine Creature, pulls me aside, and tels me I must be his Second; I go with him, we Fight, Disarm our Men, but when I came back the Bird was flown. nor cou'd I learn any News of her.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: I hat's very unlucky.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: 'Twas a Disaster never to be recover'd, a Total over-throw to all my happiness: I had not seen him neither these six Months.

sp.speaker: Merry
sp.p: Why did you not refuse him?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: He's a Malicious Fellow, and wou'd have told the whole Town of it, if I had; it was Impossible. I lost her in this Street.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Are you sure of that? I'le be Sober a Twelve Month, if this be not the very young Woman Dangerfield presented this Afternoon, to Belamira, your Brothers Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: There was a Man follow'd her.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: The very same: and that was his Servant Smoothly.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: You know her then?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Not I; but I know whither she went

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Dost know where she is, my Dear Merryman?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Don't I tell you she was presented to Bellamira by Dangerfield, your Brother's Rival?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: A Mighty Prince this Dangerfield, that is able to mak such a Present: My Brother will have a hard time on't.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: You wou'd say so indeed, if you saw his Present.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: An Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: What, that Illfavour'd Fellow he bought yesterday, that looks like an old Woman or a Ginnoy Ape?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: He that earries him will be kick'd out of Doors with his Present.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: I hope not so; for I have promis'd to diliver him.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: I did not know Bellamira was our Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: She is lately come hither.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Is she very handsome?

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: She is well.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Not comparable to mine.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: That's your fancy: Of Children Mistresses, and Religions our own are still the best.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: But is there no way to come at her? Thou usest to be good at a dead lift: I'le Fire the house and then at least I shall see her again.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Violent waies are to be us'd at last: I'le see what I can do for you.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Oh happy Eunuch! that art to live in the same house with this Divine Creature.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Why so? the nearer he is to a fine Woman, the more sensible must he be of his loss.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: But he'l see continually his fair fellow Servant, sit by sometimes and talk with her, eat with her, and if nothing else, sleep near, and hear her breath.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: What if I should make you this happy man?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: It is Impossible: but speak; men past recovery are pleas'd to talk of Remedies.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I am intrusted to present this Eunuch to Bellamira: what if you put on his Cloaths, and went with me in his room?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: I'd gladly change Conditions, Fortunes, and every thing but one with him.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I will present you instead of him; and you shall injoy those rare Felicities you reckon'd but up now, you shall sit by her, dress and undress her, touch, play with, and sleep near her; your age and Face will easily pass you for an Eunuch, and somwhat mend your Brother's ill-favour'd Present.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: You say right: I never knew a better design; let's about it instantly, undress me, dress me, and bring me to her immediately.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: You are too hot: I was but in jest all this while.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Cut my Throat, Stab me, if thou wilt not go on with this design.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Let me think a little: Is not this Plot too fine spun to hold? you must be gelt indeed, or 'twill never pass; you will betray your self.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Never fear it, my Face is not so much as known among 'em, the Plot is admirable, and cannot fail, what shou'd I do there, if I were gest?

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: You might look upon, touch, and sleep near your fair Fellow-Servant.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: That won't do: I must and will enjoy her; thou'lt hear of me in Bedlam else.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I shall have all the blame: besides, 'tis a dishonest action.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: To save a Friend's life, is an honest action: nor can it be any wrong, to Cozen those that Cozen all the World.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I'le serve you for once; but if any mischief comes on't, thank your self.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: I'le dye, and never accuse thee.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: You are strangely smitten at the first sight!

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: No. I saw her once when I was last in Spain, kneel'd by her at Mass, and talk'd of Love to her; but coul'd not learn her Name or Quality: next day, she said she was to come for England.
I might have been drest, and there by this time, le'ts away.

div.stage: Enter Bellamira, Isabella, and This be.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My dearest Isabella! now I have gotten thee here, I cou'd hug thee to pieces.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I am your Slave, your Servant, and all my Hopes the Creatures of your Goodness.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How did thy Youth and Beauty scape the roaring Dangerfield?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: He plac'd me with his Sister in the house, and she took care of me; but if at any time he offer'd to be rude, I held a Dagger to my Breast, and vow'd to kill my self.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How chance he did not take it from thee?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: He did, and then I vow'd I'de starve my self to Death: he laugh'd at me a while; but when he saw me pale, and weak, fully resolv'd to perish, he gave it me again: and so I escap'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Isabella, tell me truly, wert thou ne'r in Love?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: What mean you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Did'st thou never find a Man more Charming than the rest, whose every word reach'd through thy Ears, thy Heart, whom thou cou'd'st sit and gaze upon all day, and sigh, and wish for all night?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I have so many defects already, why will you press me to own a weakness, perhaps you will despise me for?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, I my self have been in Love, and have had alwaies some one Friend to whom I wou'd gladly sacrifice what I got from others.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: If that be to be in Love, I never was.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That's our way, who know the Perjuries and Vislanies of Men; How they all begin alike, with Vows, Oaths, and Protestations; and end alike with Slights and Scorns and Falshood: some difference there may be for a while, but no great matter.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: And are they all of this deceitful make?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: All that ever I met with; What is it a false hearted Man won't swear to such a pretty young Creature as thou art?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: And will they Lye too, when they have Sworn?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Most certainly; but we that have experience, mind words no more than they themselv's do, and only regard their Presents. Say a kind thing! every pitiful Fellow can do that: give me a Man that will do a kind thing.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Are you upon that subject? I have a couple of Servants, one is as much too Lean, as the other is too Fat; I wou'd not lose one of 'em for the World, they are Admirable in Consort, Grumbling Base, and Squeaking Treble.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What, Merryman your Guardian and Cuningham?

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: The same; Men of Wit both: one a plain substantial Drunkard, I am sure to hear of him when he gets a Bottle in his Head, for then he ever thinks of Women; as Cowards do of Quarrelling, and most commonly I am she.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How does the other behave himself?

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: He's seldom in a condition to drink Wine; but he will sit a whole Afternoon at Cards, and say the softest things!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And the sharpest behind your back.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: 'Tis all one for that, 'tis like I am even with him at the Years End.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But prety Isabella will not make her Confession to us.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: 'Tis not worth your hearing. When I was Sold to Dangerfield by your wicked Uncle, in Spain I saw a man,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That's my dear Girl! Come up with it.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Of the Divinest Form these Eyes had e're beheld.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Ne'r be asham'd: Love, like the Small Pox, since it must be, is best had while we are young.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: He Kneel'd by me one day at Mass, and look'd, and said, and sigh'd, the kindest things! He seem'd surpris'd with me, as I was Charm'd with him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Damn'd wheadling Rogue! And all this at first sight I warrant.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: We never met, but then: next day I came for England: but sure I never shall be won to love another.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pretty Innocence! this is a Nation of such men thou talk'st of; every Street affords a dozen of 'em. Come, thou shalt Love, and Love, and Love again, never fear it.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: We'l shew her the Park, the Play-house, and the Drawing-Room.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She needs no Paint, for Complexion, but 'twill not be amiss to to use Juniper Water, for good Humor, she is so melancholy, and looks as if she would not be acquainted.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: It is fit men make the advance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Some are such Jades, they must be Spur'd up, with a quick Eye, or wanton Glance.

sp.speaker: Silence.
sp.p: Madam the Picture drawer staies for you: he saies you need not sit above half an hour.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: This is some new Intrigue: Who is this Picture for?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It was begun for Keepwell, but I have promised it to Dangerfield. I hate the boistrous Fool, he may have that, but never the Original, tho he shall pay for every Inch on't.
sp.stage: Ex. all but Silence and Betty.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: We are Servants and must be diligent in our Calling. I am sorry we are like to be troubl'd with this puling Isabella, there's more ado with her, then with my Mistress herself: she is so proud and Melancholly, one can't get a word from her in a day.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Who can blame her? she is well Born of a good Family in Devonshire; her Father and Mother dy'd when she was a Child, she has no friend left but her Brother, and him she knows not where to find yet, and if she shou'd, 'tis doubtful after being so long lost, whether he wou'd own her now.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: As the World goes 'tis like he may be willing to save her Portion

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: She has nothing at present to depend upon, but the Friendship of Bellamira: and if she be vertuous, as I believe she is, what a trouble must that be to her! Go and see if she wants any thing.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Let's both go I hate a strange Face.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Especially if it be better than your own.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: I Fear poor Bellamira will lay it to Heart, I have not seen her yet: how does she like my Present?

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: She is Ravish'd with it: yet seems to Prise the Giver Incomparably beyond the Gift.

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: I'le say that for Dangerfield, and a Figue for him, he makes his Presents with the best Grace of any Man in England, they are always well received.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: I have observ'd it ever. A Beating is better taken from you then any Man living.

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: I thank 'em for that; who dares do otherwise?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Hold your Countenance, for yonder's Dangerfield.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Never doubt me: Tho I could laugh heartily, at this Martial Dress, and Furious Meen.

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: What ever was bravely perform'd in the Army, I still had the Honour on't; the General wou'd have it so: to others he was not so Favorable.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: He that has your Wit, will make a small Service go a great way; and often Reap in safety, the Fruit of other Mens dangers

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: Right: Not but I venture my Body as bravely as the meanest Soldier, when the General will let me, but, to say the Truth he seldom will, he loves me so Intirely,

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: You charge as if you were Shot-free.

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: 'Tis my Comfort, that he that Shoots one Bullet into me, may chance to drive another out. The General wares me next his Heart, and often Trusts the Army to my single Conduct.

sp.speaker: Smooth
sp.p: It shews he is well Skil'd in Men.

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: And if at any time he's Tir'd with Impertinence of Suitors; the Noise and tumults Incident to his great Charge; he steals away with a Friend or two to me, there he unfolds his Wrinkled-Brows and Steeps his Cares in Wine within my Tent.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: The General, it seems, understands his Pleasure, and knows good Company.

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: No Man better. The Officers began to Envy me, and Mutter some od things; speak out the Boldest of'em dare not. How does this Feather become me?

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: Most Victoriously; You look like the Black Prince when he, had just Plum'd the Prince of Denmark

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: Thou art a pretty Historian, I have been told I am like him: but I'le tell thee, a certain young Captain, Bolder then the rest, seeing me Gay and Frolick, lashing every Body with my Wit, as thou know'st my way is; Sneer'd me in the Face, and ask'd me, if I wou'd never have Sown my wild Oats? I told him I cou'd never Sow'em in a better time, than when there was such a Goose as he by to pick'em up.

sp.speaker: Smooth
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! You put the Goose upon him finely there; but what said he?

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: Nothing: the whole Company Laugh'd on my side; and he sneak'd away like a Dog, with a Bottle at his Tail.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: I'le say that for you, You are the best at Repartees!

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: This is the most Flalttering Knave, and Dangerfield the greatest Coxcomb, I ever saw.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: He Swallows any thing: they are well met.

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: Did'st never hear how I serv'd the Collonel, at Bartholomew-Fair?

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: (He has told it me Fifty times; but I must prepare to Laugh at it again.) Never Sir; I long to hear it.

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: I had a pretty Wench with me; he star'd her in the Face somewhat Rudely: at last I told him, I wonder'd he that was but but a Hare himself, shou'd have a mind to a Cony!

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: That's one of the vilest Quibbles, I ever heard.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Let's hear how that Rogue will Flatter him for it.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! You had as good have call'd him Coward: a Hare is the fearfullest of all Beasts. Ha, ha, ha! I cou'd dye with Laughing, methinks I see him poor Fool!

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: I meant it so; but he durst not understand me. From that time forward I kept the whole Town in Awe with my Wit

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: I wou'd not come under your Lash, for a Thousand Pounds.

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p:
No, no, thou art an honest Fellow, and a great Judge of Wit and Parts. Thou shalt hear me Sing a Song that I made upon a Spanish Princess.
SONG.
When first I made Love to my Cloris,
Cannon Oaths I brought down
To Batter the Town,
And I find her with Amorous Stories.
Billets Doux like small Shot did ply her,
And sometimes a Song
Went whizizng along,
But still I was never the nigher.
At last she sent Word by a Trumpet,
If I lik'd that Life
She wou'd be my Wife,
But never be any Man's Strumpet.
I told her that Mars wou'd not Marry,
And Swore by my Sears,
Single Combats, and Wars,
I'de rather Dig Stones in a Quarry.
But is Bellamira satisfi'd I have no concern for Isabella?

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: Havo a care of that: on the Contrary do all you can to make her Jealous. T'will keep her in Awe: and when she Names Keepwel, be sure you to Answer her with Isabella: If she commend his Dancing, be sure to praise her Singing; if she speak of his Shape, Extol her Face: give her as good as she brings; 'twill make her Mad.

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: Ay, if she Lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: How can she Chuse? Your Person, your Parts, and your Reputation, are able to Charm any Woman Living: they all Love Soldiers; and while she expects, and Loves, what you give, she Loves you, and will fear that the Stream of your Bounty shou'd turn another way.

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: Thou say'st right; I wonder I shou'd not think of it my self.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: If you had thought at all, you wou'd certainly; and of a Thousand better Devices than my poor Brains can furnish you with.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
I think I heard the Thundring Voice of my brave Man of Warr,
welcome, my Hero, my Hercules! what wou'd thy Enemies give that I cou'd hold thee thus for ever?

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: It wou'd save'em Ten Thousand Mens Lives, besides Castles, Towns, and their Dependances: but, my Life, my Joy, how dost thou like my Present? Is't not a fine Girl? I cou'd have had what Mony I wou'd of my General abroad, or here; but, I thought that below a Man of Honour: We had like to have Quarrel'd about her.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: This is a Bragging Coward, as sure as a Painted Whore has an ill Complexion of her own: How bravely he begins with his own Honour, his Courage and his General!

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: And how he magnifies his own Present! which, to say truth, another cou'd not praise too much.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I have a small Present from your banish'd Servant Keepwell; but you are going out.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not yet; but anon I must.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: What, do we stay? I am in a Feaver; I have not had Woman these two days.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: I will but deliver what was committed to my Charge for her and then leave the Feaver you complain of, to her Cure.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Some rare business, I warrant, we know the depth of Keepwel's Purse.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: You shall see that, this Girl here is of Ethiopia, of the Royal Bloud there. I le out lye him, if possible.

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: I bought a better for five Guineas, and gave her this Morning to my Landladi's Daughter.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: She looks like a Warden Roasted in the Embers, or the outside of a Gammon of Bacon.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Come forward, here's an Eunuch; a rare Jewel, how like you him?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He has a very good Face! How long have you been an Eunuch?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: I never remember my self otherwise.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: What faies Dangerfield, and Smoothly, ha, what fault do you find? They are silent, that's praise enough for an Enemy. Try him in Italian, French, Spanish, Musick, Danceing.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: If I had this Eunuch alone, he shou'd find I were none.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Go in Pisquil, and look to your Charge.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: And yet, Madam, my Friend that sends these Gifts, do's not ask that you shou'd live for him alone. Nor does he tell of his Fights; Battles, Storms, Sieges: nor does he boast ef his Scars as some do; but, when it shall be no trouble to you and when you please, think it enough if he then be Receiv'd.

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: You are very officious for your Friend Sir.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: I shall take a time to tell you, what you are, Sir

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: Officious for your Friend! Ha, ha, ha! You had as good have call'd him Pimp.

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: What dost Laugh at?

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: At what you said to him even now.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Thou that cast stoop to Flatter him thus, woud'st Eat Fire in a Fair for thy living, or Rake thy Meat off from a Dunghil

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Let's not go together.

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: I long to play my lower Tire of Guns at thee.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Go before to the Walk you know of by Kensington, and I'le meet you there.

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: I'll fly thither, as I were to beat up an Enemy's Quarters.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If Eustace comes hither; when I am away, desire him to stay: If not, to come again: If he cannot, bring him to me; you know where I Sup: Be sure you take care of Isabella, and let none come to her but the Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Why dost gaze and follow me thus, as if thou wert my Shadow?

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: I am the Shadow of a Man indeed.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Leave me; and when I want thy Attendance, I will send for thee.

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: Bellamira charg'd me, not to stir from you, 'twou'd ill become me to disobey her first Commands.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Thou art my Gaoler then?

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: Not so; I am your faithful Servant, and hope my Attendance, as it is to me a Pleasure, is to you no Burthen.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Wert thou ne'r in Spain?

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: Why do you ask?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I know not, only a Foolish Curiosity I had: but' is Impossible. Joy seeks out Crouds, and Numbers; but Griefs, like mine affect Retirement.

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: You do Indulge your Melancholy too much; If I may be so Bold, it strik's an Air of Sadness through the House.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I wou'd not have my Griefs Infectious: Go play among your Fellows.

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: I have no power to stir.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: I fear you'l do your self some mischief, when I am gon: I dare not trust the Tempest on your Brow.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: It is a harmless Storm, and will fall suddenly in Tears.
The more I look upon this Youth, the more I think on him I lov'd in Spain: Those Eyes, that Face, and that bewitching shape!

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: Pray leave me.
If I have offended, be gracious; and chide me; but do not thrust me from your presence.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Alas! I find no fault with thee at all; 'Tis Fate and my unhappy Stars, that I repine at.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Madam, the Bath that was Commanded, is prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: There I may steep my Limbs, but not my Grief asswage.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: The more I think of Bellamira's sending after me in this manner, the more I am to seek what she means. When I went first to her, she entertain'd me with a deal of Discourse, far fetch'd, nothing to the purpose: At last she ask'd me, how long my Father and Mother had been Dead? I told her, a great while; then if I had not a Seat in Devonshire, near the Sea? which I have. May be she has a mind to it, and thinks to get it of me. At last, if I had not lost a young Sister? who she was with, and what she had about her when she was lost? What she ask'd all these Questions for, I cannot guess; unless she wou'd put her self upon me for that Sister, but if she be alive, she cannot be above seventeen; and Bellarima is as old as my self. Now she shall speak her mind ploinly, or trouble me no more. Is your Mistress within.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: No; but she desires to speak with you to Morrw, about the old business.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Come hither, let me talk with you a little about the old business.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I'le come no nearer; I know your Tricks well enough.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Will Ten Guineas do you any harm?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Nor Twenty neither; but what shall I tell my Mistress? Will you come?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: I go into the Country to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Pray come: She say's you'l repent it, if you do not:

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: I can't possibly.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Will you stay here at our house, till she comes in?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Yes if you'l stay with me.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Not I. You do so touse and tumble one, and keep one so hot.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Thou art a pretty Maid, and may'st be a Mistress thy self. I have seen worse Faces in Glass Coaches.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: And better in Bridewell. I think I might serve for a Month or two; but what then?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Nay, if you be so cautious, you'l never have a house in the Mall.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Nor Dye in a Ditch, like Jane Shore.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Pattens, Worsted Stockins, and course Smocks, go with thee for a Fool.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Will you go to my Mistress where she sups anon, and I'le bring you to her?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: But come hither, prethee come, you are as skittish, as if you were that same all over. She is as Nimble as a Squirrel, there's no catching her.

div.stage: Enter Cuningham, Thisbe, and her Maid.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Come, now we are alone, sing me the last New Song.

lg.l: With want of pity for your pain,
You may be handsome, and have Wit,
The Person Love must to us fit,
Some Dye, yet never are believ'd;
Helping our selves to be deceiv'd,

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Your humble Servant Madam: I left some Friends of yours at the Rose; Merryman begun your health in a Bumper. I had much ado to get away; but your Commandsâ€”â€”

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: No body here sent for you; and of all Men living, I least expected you

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: When I received this pretty Billet Doux, my Heart went pit-a-pat; and knew 'twas your's before I open'd it.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: 'Tis a false Heart, believe it not another time.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: If it be false, it was yourBeauty first made it so.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Lightly come, lightly go; and if I lose it, to another.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: No Madam, you Conquer like the King of France. Your Subjects for ever after are at rest.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: You said as much to the Flame-colour'd Petticoat in New Spring Garden.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: She has Spies upon me; 'tis a good sign! There was a Lady I must confess much of your hight, your shape and meen; at first I thought it was your self, and therefore I accosted her: And when I was entred into discourse, she ply'd me so fast with the Intrigues of the Town, I cou'd not handsomly get off.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: I am not jealous of her: You need not take all this pains to clear your self Was she of Quality?

sp.speaker: Cun
sp.p: Yes, sure: She knew me, and desired my Protection against some Bullies that were there. Your Note here speaks of Company that were to meet at Cards; but 'tis more obliging in you to be thus alone.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Thou incorrigible piece of Vanity! I neither sent for thee to Cards, nor any thing else. Let's see this Note: 'Tis a Scriv'ner's hand.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I have heard yours commended, and am apt to hopeâ€”

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: The most that ever I knew any man.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Those pretty Lips shou'd be corrected, for their pouting, and press'd with Kisses into their former Figure.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: You shou'd be corrected, and made know your distance.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I am sorry to find you in so ill a humour, but I'le swear, that time at Spring Garden, we searce spoke of any thing but your self: She as 'tis the manner of fine Women one of another, maliciously enough, but I, with all the tenderness and transport imaginable. I see Merryman coming; I will take some fitter time for an Ecclaircissement.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: This Fellow has Vanity enough to extract Love out of an affront.
and wou'd Kiss the pretty Foot that shou'd Kick him down Stairs: He thinks all this is meer jealousie.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: These are those that can come, come without being sent for.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Or they shou'd not come at all for me.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: We have drunk every Letter of your Name twice over; and spelt it with a double Eat last.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: 'Twas done like a discret Guardian: You are drunk then.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: No; half a score Glasses do but whet Wit and sharpen Appetite: A Bottle is the Spring-Tide of Love, and dull Sobriety the Lowest Ebb.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: I love to see things at the worst, that I may know what to trust to.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: You wou'd not be seen so your self: Don't you Ladies Dress, Patch and Curl, and Paint too, if there be occasion before you come abroad?

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: That's to please our selv's, and in competition to one another.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: And that competition is about us filthy Fellows Was not Cunning ham here?

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: He's just gone.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I sent him to you: We had a mind to drink a Bottle by our selv's, and cou'd not get rid of him, till I contriv'd a Letter in your Name for him. He shew'd it us like a vain Fool, immediatly

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: He'le tell the whole Town: Pray undeceive him when y ou see him next; for all I cou'd say cou'd not do it.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Have you any Mirabilis?

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: I shou'd not see you so often if I had not.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: We good Fellows have our Qualms, like Breeding Women.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: And your great Bellies too, most of you: Which you go to lay at Epsome, and Tunbridge Waters.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: When we are Marry'd I'le turn over a New Leaf.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Hold, 'tis not come to that yet; you are the envy of your Club Four Hundred Pounds a Year, and neither Wife nor Child, and spend it all in Drink.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I am very conjugally given: I love of late to drink hand to hand with an old Friend; have left off supping, and go to Bed at Ten.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: These are signs of a Body far spent in the service.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I will leave off drinking, Eat much, and get Children innumerable.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Not till you have been Flux'd: You are an old sinner, and I dare not venture upon you.

sp.speaker: Merr:
sp.p: I am as sound as a Bell, Fat, Plump, and Juicy, and have drunk my Gallon a day these seven Years.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: However, 'twill mend your shape.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I have been told, I am as true a shap'd Drunkard as heart can wish; Great Belly, double Chin, thick Legs: You wou'd not have a Pad look like a Racer?

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: No; but I wou'd have you thought to get your Children, if I Marry you.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I'le Cut any Man's Throat that says the contrary.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: But they will whisper and make Libels: Your great Belly will be a continual jest upon mine.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I will Drink Raking Rhenish, Eat Butter'd Wheat, Sweat in the Bagnio, and do any reasonable thing, to render my Person Gracious.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Every Jocky will do as much, to win a Tankard; but I must have no Morning Draughts, no Qualms that keep off Dinner till three a Clock, no Tun-belly'd Rogues, that fright Chair-men from the house, no Noisie Fools to disturb the whole Street with Loyal Catches, & senseless Huzzah's.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I have some Provisoes to offer too, in order to our future Peace and Quiet: I will have none of your Gaming Ladies to keep you up at Cards till I am ready to go out in the Morning, so that we have scarce time for the great end of Matrimony. No meetings at the China-houses; where under pretence of Rafling for a piece of Plate, or so, you get acquainted with all the Young Fellows in Town; three such accidental meetings go to visit, and three visits to something that shall be Nameless. No Epsome nor Tunbridge Waters, where Ladies and Gentlemen walk and prate up acquaintance, as fast as if it were in a Tavern.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: You must either get me with Child the first Year, or give me leave to use the Lawful Means: I hope I may visit Bellamira.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: She is not so handsome as she was, and begins to look something procurish; she is more dangerous than any Man; one Setter destroys more Patridge than ten Hawks, when you take me for better for worse, you must forsake her and all her Works.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: When you take me for Rich or for Poor, you shall either leave your Drink or your Jealousie. I will not be troubled with an Italian and a Dutch Man, bound up in one Greasie Volume.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: 'Tis a mad Age, a Man is Laught at for being a Cuckold, and wonder'd at if he take any Care to prevent it; well, I will leave all to thy discretion; and as thou hast been careful of thy own Credit hitherto, hope thou wilt be as tender of mine when I am thy Husband.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p:
That's all you have to trust too: Now to shew you I will not be out-done in Generosity, you shall Dine in the City, and get Drunk among your old Companions sometimes; but I will have no Women
brought into the Company, on any pretence whatever.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: My Land-lady, an Oyster-Wench, or so.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Not if she be under Fifty; you may be drunk at home: I will Dine with you, to keep off Beer Glasses while you Eat.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Content: I have a beastly Bumper at my Meals; we will have two Beds, for I will not come home drunk and get Girls, without I knew where to get Portions for 'um; in this Age they sowre and grow stale upon their Parents hands. Luorece's will scarce off, but to Forraigners.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: A young Gentleman in the Street hard by, says he must speak with you immediately.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: 'Tis One of your drunken Companions; you had best go to him, we shall have him come hither else.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I wou'd Kick the best Friend in Christendom down Stairs, shou'd he offer it. Adieu for a while.

div.stage: Enter Bellamira in Man's Cloaths, to her Merryman.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: What's you business with me Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If you will walk a little farther into the Square, I'le satisfie you, Sir.

Now we are alone, the time and place convenient, I must tell you; you abus'd a person of Quality last Night, forc'd open her Lodgings, beat her Servants, broke her Windows, and call'd her all the Names imaginable.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: That may very well be; I went home drunk, and scour'd outragiously: But what of that?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am her Brother.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: And come to swagger in her behalf?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am come for satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Her Name, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Emilia.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Her Lodging?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The Flower de Luce.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I always took it to be a Baudy-house,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It seems so; but I come to convince you to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Sir, I believe you: And if you will bring me to wait on her, I will ask her Pardon: I am as much asham'd of a rudness offer'd to a Person of Quality, when I am sober, as any Man living.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I thought what a Fellow I shou'd find.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: My little Bully, will nothing serve you but Battle, Murder and sudden Death?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I came to fight Sir; not to hear you prate.
sp.stage: They go to Fight, Bellamira pulls up. her Peruke.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Then pluck out, that I may Tap thee presently.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold, hold Merryman; dost thou not know me yet?

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Bellamira in disguise!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Why this to me? Faith you shall never find me backward to Man or Woman.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, thou art a brave Fellow, I have occasion for such a one, and (now I have try'd you, and see you dare fight) all's well,

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Am I to be your Ladyships Second?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: An easier Business.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I have appointed Dangerfield to wait for me in the Walk neer Kensington, which I so much delight in: Thus disguised I intend to Rob him, and have chosen thee for my Fellow-Adventurer. When we have frighted the roaring Fool sufficiently, we'l find some way to give him his Mony again.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: We may be hang'd together very lovingly in earnest, tho' we Rob in test.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If he shou'd discover, which he never will, I can prevail with him not to Prosecute; Besides, the Lying Fool will swear for his Credit, we were at least a dozen; my Heart is set upon this Frolick; don't deny me.

sp.speaker: Merr
sp.p: 'Tis admirable! 'twill be the best News for my Friend Keepwell.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He shall know it in due time I hate this Danger field, and now I have gotten Isabella out of his hands, I care not if he were hang'd.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: And shall we Cudgel his Buff Coat sufficiently?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Till it be as gentle as a Sheepskin.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Thou art a brave Wench, I Faith, I will drink thy Health hereafter by the Name of the Pretty Padder. I will borrow a Vizor of some over-grown Baud, and about it instantly. But shall we Sup together in Town afterwards?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sure you'l not wrong Friend Keepwell so much?

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Not for a World, if I thought you wou'd not; but, he is at a distance, the Temptation present, and not to be resisted by frail Man.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You were always an Enemy of mine; and vet I know not how, I ever lik'd your blunt way? and cou'd not hate you heartily for it.

sp.speaker: Merr
sp.p: If you will make a Convert of me, this is the time.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You shall then promise me drunk or sober, to speak well of me to Keepwell.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: That's too hard, but, if I speak any ill of you, drunk: I will promise to deny it again when I am sober.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You shall never more tell him I will undo him, nor read him any discreet Lectures about my extravagance in Cloaths, Furniture, Equipage, Hours, or Company.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I never did sow diffention but with intent you shou'd make your benefit of it; for I am told after every little Quarrel, he buys his peace with a Coach and Horses, a Country House, Pearl Necklace, or some such trifle.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He does so; yet, but frequent Disputes may end in a Breach, and there are many fine Women that lie upon the Catch, to get him from me.

sp.speaker: Merr:
sp.p: Fear him not, next to you he loves Money, and will never begin such another Expence in a new place. You have more Plate, than ten Christ'nings, more China, than many a Shop, more good Cloaths than the Play house.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You had like to have undone me for all that, with your Stories; but he told me all when I had him alone.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I don't doubt it; I see advice is thrown away upon him, and I will trouble him with no more; but, be thy Servant to all intents and purposes.
Now the Peace is agreed on, we'll Sign and Seal anon.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You'l tell him one time or other when you are drunk together.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: He'll not believe me if I shou'd. Well I am a Rogue to betray my Friend thus; but, who wou'd not be taken off with such a Bribe? Besides, in matter of Women, we are all in the State of Nature, every man's hand against every man. Whatever we pretend.

sp.speaker: Eust.
