sp.p: I wonder what's become of Lionel; he has not appear'd this day or two. I will go to Bellamira's and know where she Sups that I may meet her, and know the end of her affair with me. Who's this walks this way? He is transported, and talks to himself.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: If a man car'd to be alone he shou'd be troubled with forty Coxcombs, and ten times as many impertinent Questions: But now I am ready to burst with Joy, and Secrets, I can meet no Friend to vent my self to.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p:
This is Lionel, for all his disguise, I know him. How now,
Lionel? What's the meaning of this habit? I never saw a man so overjoy'd: are you in your Wits?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Friend! There is not a man on Earth, to whom I would so gladly impart my secret Joy, or inward Grief as to thy self.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: 'Tis the happiness of friendship that the one is improv'd, the other lessen'd, by our doing so: But what means all this?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: I am impatient till you know; this is the happiest day of all my Life: And I cou'd be contented to die this Minute, least some succeeding Misfortunes shou'd defile this sincere Joy. You know Bellamira, my Brothers Mistress.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: I have seen her twice or thrice.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: There was this day a young Maid given her by Dangerfield my Brothers Rival, the finest Creature that ever my Eyes beheld; not above seventeen, a man flying for his Life wou'd stop to gaze upon her.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: I am not of your opinion, but what of her?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Seeing her in the Street, I fell in Love with her. By good fortune, we had an Eunuch, which my Brother had promis'd to Bellamira: Nor was he yet dellver'd; Merriman, who undertook to carry him advis'd me, seeing me dying for this young Woman.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: What did he advise you?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: To change Cloaths with this Eunuch, and be presented to Bellamira, in his stead.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: What, for an Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: I have a pretty Voice, Smooth Chin.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: What cou'd you propose to your self?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: To see her, and be alone sometimes with the Divine Creature: Do you count all that nothing? In short, I was presented to Bellamira, and received with great Joy, and without the least Suspicion, she left me at home, and recommended this beautiful Creature to my sole care.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: She did it.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Most discreetly.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Most fortunately. I'le tell thee more, she commanded no Body shou'd come near her, but my self; and that I shou'd not stirr from her, in the farthest part of the house. I Blush'd, look'd down, and modestly said it shou'd be done.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Oh Rogue! thy Discourse has Fingers in it.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Bellamira goes but to Supper; her Servants follow her, except some of the meanest sort: Presently they prepare a Bath for the fair Stranger; this beautiful Creature is call'd to go into the Bath.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: What before you?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Yes, before an Eunuch sure. She goes in, returns, the Servants put her to Bed: I ask if they have any service for me: Pisquil, says one, (for so I was call'd) Take this Fan, and cool my Mistress with it, as she lies.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Oh, that I cou'd have seen thee with those gloating Eyes, Fanning a Naked Woman! an Asinego as thou art.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Presently all the Maids run, some one way, some another, as Servants do when their Masters are abroad; in the mean time this beautiful Creature falls asleep: I look about me, to see if all were fast, I Bar the Door,

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Lion
sp.p: What then, my Eustace? Can you ask and know me? Shou'd I have slipt so fair, so wish'd, so unexpected an Opportunity, I must have been that Eunuch that I seem'd.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: You ravish'd her then,

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: What else? I took her by Storm, having no leisure for a Siege; I found her the same Woman I fell in Love with in Spain.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: She we so often talk'd of?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: The same: and which is more, she remembred me again: Never was Man so Happy! never was Accident so Fortunate!

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Did she not Cry out?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: There was no Body within hearing.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: 'Twas somthing a harsh way.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: No Woman ever heartily fell out with a Man about that Business, I'le try to soften her in my own Person!

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Won't you change your Cloaths?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: How shall I change 'em? Or whither shall I go? I dare not go home, for fear of my Brother: Then again, if my Father shou'd be come out of the Country!

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Come to my house, out of the Street however.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Agreed.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: 'TIs strange Bellamira appears not, we have been here a great while.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: I wonder she mak's no more hast to her own happiness! the Spanish Ladies wou'd not have serv'd you so.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Nay, I'le speak a bold word; French, Spanish, or Italian; I was ever the delight of Ladies, I was the Terror of Men.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: Perhaps she has been overturn'd, broke a Wheel, or some such Accident: may be her sneaking Lover's return'd.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Who Keepwell? that fearful Hind, that ran out of Town at the News of my Arrival, least I shou'd Kick him to Jelly?

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: 'Tis almost Night, what if we shou'd be Robb'd here?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: What if the Skie shou'd fall? or a Flock of Sheep root a marching Army? If all these Hedges were lin'd with Musqueteers I wou'd not yield.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: If a Hog shou'd start out and rustle, he wou'd run away. [Aside. A Volley of Shot is Musick to your great-Heart; but what shall poor I do?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: This Fellow is as Cowardly as I am Rash, and Advent'rous, Creep behind me, and be as safe as in a Brazen Tower, I'le shew thee how I kill'd Don Alonzo in Spain.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: I dare not stand: You'l run such a Fellow as I through with a Scabbardon.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: On my Honour, as I love danger, I will not hurt thee. He ran furiously upon me.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: And did you look so terribly, as you do now?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Worse if possible.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: He was a brave Man then.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: The bravest Fellow I ever had to do with: He had Kill'd Nine Men in Duel, made two and twenty Campagns, been in eight Sea-Fights and thirteen pitch'd Battles.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Here he is Fencing with his Man.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: Thieves, Thieves! Murder! Look to your self.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your Mony.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Deliver Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Take it you Scoundrels, and thank Heav'n I am not in an angry Mood

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Will a good Cudgle put you into it?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: No: Venus, Venus, rules the day, I am all Peace and Love: My Vigour is defign'd to other purposes than Fighting with Rascally Fellows.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: We must have this Pearl out of your Ear.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: 'Twas given me for my service at the Siege of Dunkirk, as a Mark of Honour.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Make hast, we shall be forc'd to Crop you else.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Let's remove 'em a little farther, and tie 'em Back to Back, and leave 'em.

sp.speaker: Dan
sp.p: I'le have satisfaction for this Affront, you Rascals, I scorn the slow pac'd Revenge of Law, 'tis Blood I'le have.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: That you may not forget, I will give you this farther Remembrance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come away with the Rascals.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Well, Stripling well, no more to be said.

sp.speaker: 1. Bay.
sp.p: I'le stay no longer sending up and down: Can you pay the Mony?

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: In a short time I can.

sp.speaker: 2. Bay.
sp.p: Have you any Friend that will be bound with you?

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: I have; but I am so unfortunate, they are not within.

sp.speaker: 1. Bay.
sp.p: Come, come, away to Prison.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: If you have the Hearts of Men, take Pitty on my Youth. This is all the Mony I owe in the World, and I shall suddenly discharge it; but if you disgrace me thus, I am undone for ever.

sp.speaker: 1. Bay.
sp.p: We are Officers, and must obey our Warrant. Come along.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What's here Thisbe in the hands of Bailiffs! I will Kill two Birds with one Stone at once, I will shew my Courage, and my Love in rescuing my Mistress. Let's never suffer these Rascals to carry her off.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: I will not Fight against the Law: A Bailiff and a Hangman are as necessary as a Lord Chief Justice, in a Government.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I will draw and be Knock'd down, in her Quarrel by my self then.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Hold, hold: I will draw my Purse and rescue her a surer way.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Is there no way for my deliverance?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I'le Bail her.

sp.speaker: 1 Bay.
sp.p: We must have City Security; no Covent Garden Bully?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: What's the Sum?

sp.speaker: 1. Bay.
sp.p: Two Hundred Pound. What do we stand talking with her? away.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Oh I am Miserable!

sp.speaker: Cun
sp.p: Hold, you shall have your choice of six Play Debts: Sir Thomas Whiskin ows me three hundred pound; will you take that for your Mony? or Harry Huthead shall be your Pay-master.

sp.speaker: 1. Bay.
sp.p: Nothing but our Mony down, or good Security.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Why, Then here's your Mony down you Rascals.

sp.speaker: 2 Bay.
sp.p: Now you say something. Much good may do you: She is very pretty, and as cheap as Neck-Beef.

sp.speaker: This
sp.p: This Redemption as I never can deserve, so I cannot too much acknowledge your surprising Generosity to a Stranger, known to you by nothing but distress.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Preserve your thanks till you find to whom they are due, I am but the Instrument of your deliverance, and was employ'd by a Servant of yours, who cou'd not come himself, for some reasons you shall know hereafter.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: May I not know his Name? that I may return him his Mony at least.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: He charg'd me to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I cou'd almost forswear Play, since my ill Fortune has put me out of condition of doing this small Service, but I was ready with my Sword.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: 'Tis much better as it is.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I did not throw one mam in two hours, I lost three sets at Back-Gammon, and a Tout at Tricktrack, all ready Mony; the rude Fellows have frighted the Roses from your Cheeks.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: This Rogue my Taylor that Arrested me, came but three days ago to know if I had any service to command him: There must be something farther in't.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Perhaps some envious Woman set him on: there is as much malice among the Beauties as among Wits: Will you give me leave to wait on you home! there are rude Fellows abroad, and you may meet with some Affront.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Madam we will secure you from that.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: How does my dearest Bellamira? Does she not think I have mortified my self enough.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: You may guess: She is gone out with Dangerfield.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I know it too well

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Oh this Villain, Viper, Satyr! where shall I find him? or how torment him when I have found him? we are all undone, Abus'd Cheated!

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: My heart misgives me strangely, and I have scarce Courage to ask what's the matter. Here have been Scourers, breakers of Windows.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: As soon as he had his will of her, to run away, and leave us thus! but if I light of him, I'le tear his Goatish Eyes out.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Here has been some disorder in my abscence: who is't you threaten thus? whom do you speak of?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: As if you did not know, and be hang'd with your pretious Gifts.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: They are such your Mistress wou'd never let me rest till she had 'em: if she don't like 'em, now, she may thank her self.
But what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: The Eunuch you gave us made brave work!

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Oh, is that all? not work for a Midwife, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: It may be in time. He has Ravish'd the young maid Dangerfield gave my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible: he is as innocent as the Child Unborn.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: What he is I cann't tell; but by his works, he's no more an Eunuch than your self: the young Maid is all in Tears: We cannot get a Word from her: Pray Heaven she does herself no mischief She casts down her Eyes, and sighs as if her heart wou'd break; The Rascal's no where to be found; 'tis well if he have not robb'd us at parting too.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I am strangely amaz'd he knows no place in Town no person, and has no where to go, but to my House.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Let's see if he be there. Our Maids have swom every one to have a Limb of him.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I have heard these Eunuchs have been very amorous; but never heard of such a Prank: besides this was taken in an Algerine, an Eunuch after the Turkish manner.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: He look'd so demurely, I thought Butter wou'd not have melted in his Mouth, I hope you will make sure work with him before you send him again. But see Isabella herself.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I'll speak to her, and know the truth.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: You had better step aside and observe her: you'l put her out of Countenance.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Torn from my Parents and my Country young;
Then in a Foreign Land expos'd to Sale.
After some few removes when but a Child,
I to the hands of Bellamira fell,
Then to rude Dangerfield by Fortunes spite
Strangely betray'd; and now again restor'd,
I know not how, nor why, nor on what score.
Misfortune sure like mine never was.
In every Change and State I still preserv'd
My Honor boldly by Contempt of Life,
Vow'd the same hour should rob me of 'em both:
The Resolution was so new, it check'd his Lust.
But what do's it avail to keep from Thieves
That Wealth we must anon to Pyrats lose?
No sooner here, but like an Eunuch,
A bold Lover com's and rifles me of all;
Vow'd to return, Marry and take me hence;
But Men are False, Women believing Fools:
Yet this is he that Lov'd me when in Spain,
And my poor heart first kindled at his Fire
Till he returns I will not Cherish Life,
Nor sleep nor nourishment shall prop this Frame:
My Husband he will be or Murtherer

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Poor Lady! she has dissolv'd my Eyes. Her Passion's great; but I'll go home and kill Pisquil: thou shalt go and see the Execution.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: We'l flay the Lustful Swine.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My dear man of War? bouncing Bully! did'st thou not begin to dispair of me?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: When we were ty'd back to back and thrown into that Ditch, I began to think we must have lain in the Field all Night, as I have done, for my part, half my life time.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You have not been robb'd I hope?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Yes, faith the Rogues surpriz'd us e're we cou'd get our Swords out

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not of much?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Of a hundred Pieces, and some Medals, given me by Forraign Princes and States, for my good Service in the Wars.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am the unhappiest woman in the World! and all this staying for me! how many were the Rogues?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Half a Foot Company.

sp.speaker: Smoo.
sp.p: Such as we us'd to Muster in Flanders.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How many is that English?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: A dozen Arm'd with Sword and Pistol.

sp.speaker: Smoo.
sp.p: There were more of 'em not far off if need had been.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: The Captain of 'em was such another fat fellow as Merryman: I shall know him again if I see him; and if I do; I make one entire bruise of him. He laid on me most unmercifully.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Who unbound you?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: An honest Country fellow, who came by, by accident.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I have been overthrown too by a Gentlemans Coachman, who threw us in the dirt; and I was forc'd to go home to shift.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Know you the Livery? I will have satisfaction, or make him turn away his sawcy Servant: I am rusty, for want of Fighting.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If I did I would tell you, you are so apt to thrust your self into Quarrels; 'tis a sad thing to love a brave man, a Woman is ever in one fright or other: if they have the discretion not to be Principals, they must be Seconds in every idle business.

sp.speaker: Dan
sp.p: I never fail'd but once, of disarming my man.

sp.speaker: Smoo.
sp.p: And then you had the Misfortune to run him clean through the heart.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: I fled into France upon it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What if I help you to your Money and Jewels again?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: I'll give you Fifty Pounds. Can you guess who robb'd us?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, but I'll take you at your word. Stop here at Knights-bridge, there is a Justice, swear your loss before him since you were robb'd between Sun and Sun, and the Country is oblig'd to make it good.

sp.speaker: Smoo.
sp.p: Here's Fifty pounds well gotten. This is a Witty Wench, I am half in Love with her my self.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: I had rather lose it all, then swear before one of those Children of the Gown.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay you shall do it: 'twill soon be over, and then we'll Sup in Town.

sp.speaker: Smoo.
sp.p:
Now must I forswear my self, or lose my Place: Let me see, that I may not be out: The Robbers were Twelve, the Mony lost, a
Hundred Pieces, besides Medals and Rings to the value of as much more.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Come out you Rogue, you Rascal: will nothing go down with you, but, Maiden-heads?

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: I beseech you, Sir

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: How came you hither again? What's the meaning of these Cloaths? speak; if we had stay'd never so little longer he had been gone, he was preparing for his journey, I see.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Where is he? That I may stick my Bodkin in him.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Don't you see him?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: No if I did, I'd teach him to come with his edg'd Tooles amongst poor harmless Maids.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: It might have been some of our Cases; and I pitty Isabella with all my heart: But are you sure you have him fast?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Why there he is, just before you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: What that poor Wretch? That swallow face was never within our doors. There's a Ravisher indeed!

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Cou'd you think this was he that we complain'd of?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I never had any other.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: This fellow is no more to our Pisquil, than a Calf is to a Lion.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: He you sent us had a sweet Face, delicate Shape, quick Eye, and a promising Countenance.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Fine Feathers make fine Birds: You see him now in plain Cloaths, at his worst.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: There's more in't then so: Ours was young, handsome in his prime; this is a Wither'd, Worn-out, Weather-beaten, Weasil-fac'd Fellow.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I shall begin to think I dont't know my right hand from my left, if this be true. Come hither Sirrah, Pisquil, did not I give Fifty pound for you?

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: You did, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Now let me ask him a question: Do you know our house.

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: No, nor you neither.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Merryman brought us a young fellow of Nineteen that wou'd have known us all over and over, if he had stay'd.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: How come you by these Cloaths? Why don't you answer me, you Rascal?

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: One Mr. Lionel came.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: What, my Brother?

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: He said so.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: To day.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: with whom?

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: With Merryman only.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Did you know he was my Brother?

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: Mr. Merryman told me so: he gave me these Cloaths and took away mine; then they went both together.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I am undone, Bellamira will never endure this affront, nor ever be perswaded but I was privy to it.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: It may cost you a Weeks Banishment or so; but what think you, am I sober? am I in my right Wits? No, Ily'd! I was a Fool! the Eunuch was as Innocent as a Lamb Poor Isabella! Is not she undone, ruin'd for ever.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: No, he shall marry her and make her an honest woman, will not that satisfie?

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: Alas Sir I have nothing to satisfie a woman with neither by night nor by day, I am a poor despicable Eunuch. If I Marry your Worship must get my Children and keep 'em too.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: My Mistress will never like that.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: The Wench he Ravish'd is but a Servant Maid, or at most one that has no friends, I'll give 'em a Farm of twenty pound a year, and make up all that way:

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: I beseech you Sir Drown or Hang me out of the way, but name not Marriage to a wretch in my condition.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Sirrah I'le have it so. Will nothing down with you but forbidden fruit? you have no stomach to a Woman in a lawful way and behang'd.

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: I am your true, your very Eunuch Pisquil! what pranks have been play'd in my name I know not; let any of these Maids examine me, alas! I am under no circumstances of Wedlock.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Out upon him filthy Creature, I wou'd not touch him for a World.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I had rather handle a dead Corps; three such Fellows were enough to breed a Plague.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I'll take my Corporal Oath this is not he that was at our House.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I never saw two men in my life more unlike than this odious Fellow and our Pisquil.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I am resolv'd he shall Marry her though it cost me Forty pound a year; Bellamira's House must not be thus affronted.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Sir you mistake, Isabella is a Gentlewoman sits at Table with my Mistress, and wou'd not Marry such a fellow for all you are worth.

sp.speaker: Keep
sp.p: What shall we do then?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Let's find out the true Ravisher, if he refuse to marry her, take the Law of him and Hang him.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Come hither Pisquil: Did Lionel put on thy Cloaths and leave thee his?

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: By all that's good he did.

sp.speaker: Keep
sp.p: And put on thine?

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: Yes in the Room.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: He came to us indeed in a strange fashion'd habit.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: This Lionel is the most wicked, Impudent, and I the most unhappy of mankind! I have sent a Stone-horse among Mares.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Now don't you think my Mistress has been finely serv'd by you and your lewd Brother?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I am undone if all this comes to Bellarmira's Ear: she talk'd of a great Summ she hop'd to get by restoring this young Woman to her Friends: I am afraid 'tis I must pay it now; No man will own her, having been thus abus'd. Sirrah deny all again instantly.

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: Let me alone, Sir I'll set all right.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I'll get the truth out of thee, or I'll beat thee in a Mortar. When was my Brother here?

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: Four days ago.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Never since?

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: No indeed Sir,

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: See what a Lying Rogue this is now! I have had him but two days, and he saies my Brother chang'd his Cloaths with him four dayes ago.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: He said quite otherwise but now, and that it was this day.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Damn him Rogue, he faulters in his Evidence, and I wou'd not hang a Dog upon his Testimony; are not you a fine Rascal to lay this villany upon my Innocent Brother?

sp.speaker: Pisq.
sp.p: I do confess; pray Sir pardon me, I was afraid.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Get you out of my sight you lying Rogue.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: He is a Lying Rogue now I dare swear.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: He dares not stand to his first story: Keepwell has threatned him.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: This is all Merryman's contrivance; but if I be not even with him, may I dye a Maid. Well Dangerfield and my Mistress wore at high words after Supper: She gave me her Gold and Jewels to carry home; a sure sign she'l not stay long behind.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I'll go Home.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I'll go to Merryman and learn the bottom of this business, that I may know what to say to my offended Bellamira.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: I will turn Turk but I will avoid Wine hereafter, that Aeternal Foe to better sport, Can my dear Bellamira forgive her poor entertainment.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why not, as well as you do a weak Brother who can drink but his Bottle. You may sit up till morning tho he leave you at Nine, the Application is easie.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I will leave my Mornings draught of Mum and Wormwood, and Breakfast hereafter upon new laid Eggs, Amber greece and Gravy.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Trouble not your self, I will Breakfast before I come to you, and Sup heartily before I go to bed.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: This Paunch of mine shall down, I will no longer suffer my Virile virtue to be Eclips'd by this Globe of Earth, Bisket my Meat, Fennel Water and Vinegar shall be my Drink this twelve Months.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your Pennance is too severe, meerly for a sin of Omission, I like you the better for it: Your honest nature wou'd not suffer you to wrong your friend too much, when it came to the point.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: My honest over-grown body wou'd not keep pace with lewd Will; for which I am resolv'd to mortifie it, no more Bumpers, no Dinners that last till Midnight, no City Feast, no Huzzahs.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You are in Love elsewhere, and keep your self for pretty Mistress. Thisbe.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I never saw Play, but I was willing to throw away what I had about me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well I must leave you, Keepwell I fear is in Town.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: That word leave you, alwaies puts me into a Cold Sweat, and if a man were Cock'd and Prim'd, is enough to make a man miss Fire. Can't you stay one Minute?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: To what purpose, I have been here a great while, sure 'tis late, your Company stay for you, the Bottles are upon the Table by this time.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Wou'd you had never talk'd of going, I am the worst at paying Mony upon a Pinch, can't you stay one quarter of an hour?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I have appointed business with Eustace and must be gone.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, Keepwell is coming up Stairs, I told him you were asleep, he must needs speak with you.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Step in there, I'll send him away presently.

div.stage: Enter Keepwell, he gets a glimpse of Bellamira.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Merryman with a Wench, nay then we are all Mortal.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: 'Tis only a Wine Cooper's Daughter that has brought me some tast of Pontack out of her Fathers Cellar.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Sings) Her Breasts of Delight, are two Bottles of White, and her Eyes are two Cups of Canary. I hope we shall have no more Lessons of Thrist, no pious Exhortations, no Lectures against Love: Why she has as good Cloaths as my Bellamira.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: But I don't Pay for'em as you do.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Prithee let me see her, I have trusted thee with my Bell. a hundred times.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: You won't like her and then I shall be laugh'd at, besides this is the first time, she is a young modest Sinner and I have given her my word.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: What, art thou asham'd of her?

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Nor proud of her neither, as you are of your Tyrant Bellamira.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Never speak against my Bell. she is the prittiest little pouting tempestuous Rogue sometimes, but 'tis soon over, and then she is so calm again, the Halcyon, might breed upon her Lips.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: You are grown Poetical since you went into the Country.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Prithee let me see thy Punk, thy Cockatrice, thy Harlot.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Good words, you don't know who you speak off.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I'll set my foot against the door.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: You won't be such a Brute.
sp.stage: [How shall we get rid of him?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I am very Rampant.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I have that will take down your Courage. Dangerfield has sent me a Challenge for delivering your Eunuch and Black in his Presence.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Why didst thou do it in his Presence?

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: 'Tis past now, and you must be my Second.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Pox on't I did not mean rampant for Fighting, I meant for th'other business, I have no malice to any man living but am wond'rous loving.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: We are to meet an hour hence, the time is short, I cannot possible find another Friend; besides, 'tis partly your own quarrel.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Hang him he makes a Trade of Fighting, and kills men by the year.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: We must try, what Mettle he is made off.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Let me alone, I will bring you off with Honour, and without Fighting.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: The Officer of the Guard is my intimate Friend, I will acquaint him with the Quarrel and get us all secur'd; I have scap'd hitherto by his means, and yet have sent and receiv'd some Challenges in my Life time; he saves more Bloodshed than all the Parsons in Town with their Sermons against Duelling.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I have no great Lust for Fighting, if you can take it up handsomely, with all my heart, but you must about it instantly for the time is short.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I am gone out be sure you stay at home.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I knew this was a sure way to be rid of him.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: And so must we, the Guard will be here presently else; You cou'd not help calling me Tyrant to Keepwell tho you knew I was within hearing

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I must talk a little after the old rate, 'twill breed suspicion in him shou'd I change my Note all of a suddain, but I will drink him upevery Night, and send him to thee so loving.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Drink him down rather, pray, let him alone as he is.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, how is it between my Mistress and her Man of War?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Not so as it might be between thee and me, if thou wou'dst be rul'd.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I am rull'd by my Friends and Relations.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: They'll undo thee Silence, if thou heark'nest to 'em: thou wilt spend thy Youth in Service, and in thy Age be eaten up with Children.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Better so than with the Pox: I had rather be a Coblers Wife, than the best Man's Whore in the Land.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: This is a wicked Principle, and has undone more young Women!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: If I must be ruin'd, I'll be ruin'd in an honest way.

sp.speaker: Eust:
sp.p: A Woman ruin'd in an honest way is the vilest, contemptiblest thing imaginable: give me a Woman ruin'd with a Coach and six Horses, a house in the Mall, fine Equipage! and all this thou might'st be in a fair way to Compass.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: But what of my Mistress and Dangerfield?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: They are all to pieces.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: About what?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: About a young Maid Dangerfield gave her: nothing will serve but he'll have her again.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: She will never meet with such a Loyal, Obedient Lover, as Keepwell.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: He is the Top Cully of the Town. But here she comes her self.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I believe he'll come to take her away by force; but let him offer to touch her with a Finger, I'll pluck his Eyes out. I can bear with his impertinences and big words, while they are but words; but if he offer violence, I know what he is at the bottom, and can find those that can Cudgel him.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: I have expected you a good while here.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do you know that Dangerfield's last Quarrel and mine was a Concern of yours?

sp.speaker: Eust
sp.p: He was not Jealous of me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No: but while I endeavour'd to restore your lost Sister, to you, as I think in Conscience I ought; I suffer'd what you see, and more from him.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: You have several times talk'd to me of a Sister of mine, lost from our house in Devonshire; but I always look't upon it as a meer Wheadle.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: One that has an ill name, is half hang'd: but, I assure you, I was in earnest, as I shall make appear to you by infallible Circumstances.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: I lost indeed a Sister, about twelve years since, but where she is, Heaven only knows.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes I know she is at home.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: What at your house?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes at my house: my Mother bred her, as if she had been her own, you need not be asham'd to own her.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: She bred her up from a Child! I like that well: then this is not she that Dangerfield gave her yesterday; and that Lionel Ravish'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I doubt not of your Gratitude, when you see her: She's a delicate Creature.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: How old is She?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Seventeen.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: The very Age that Lionel mention'd: I am undone again!
She had my Father's Picture on, when she was lost.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She has it still and kisses it a hundred times a day.

sp.speaker: Eust
sp.p: A bite by a Monky upon her left arm.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She has so. If I shew her you with these Tokens will you not thank me, and own her?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Yes, if you have not taught her your own Trade.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: By my Life, she is as innocent, as when you lost her first, we ever kept a strict hand over her. By good fortune Keepwell gave me a fine Eunuch, to his care I have instrusted her and charg'd him not to stir from her.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Hell, and Damnation! The Eunuch was Lionel. [Aside. I have heard as much, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Who cou'd tell you?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: I know not: I heard in the Town, you had an Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now let's have a care we don't both lose her, for this is she that Dangerfield gave and threatens to takeaway again.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: It is too apparent, no sooner found, but lost, my Isabella: Lost, to thy Fame thy Family for ever.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You seem disorder'd: are you we'l?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: A little surpris'd, at the unexpected discovery of my dear Sister. But why did you not tell me this sooner?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I had her of Dangerfield but yesterday.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Did you not tell me you were bred up together?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, but how we first met, how we parted, how Dangerfield got her, I will tell you at more leisure, he threatens to take her away by force; you are not afraid of him?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Of no man-less. I have a sudden Qualm come over me; I have drunk too much Wine.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come in I'll give you some Mirabilis.

div.stage: Enter Dangerfield, Smoothly, Bullies, and Link Boyes.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: I'll teach her to provoke a man of Honour, Culverin, Wildfire, and Hackum, follow your Leader: First I'll pull the house about their Ears.

sp.speaker: Smoo.
sp.p: Spoken like your self.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: I'll slit her Nose, then give her the Trant'vne.

sp.speaker: Smoo.
sp.p: It will be a brave revenge, and make you Terrible through the World.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Advance Culverin, with the Link-boyes: Hackum command thou the right Wing; and thou Wildfire the left.

sp.speaker: Boyes.
sp.p: Here, here, here.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: I my self will bring up the Rear, give the Sign for the on-set, and be ready to assist you with my Conduct, if need be.

sp.speaker: Smoo.
sp.p: What a Jewel is experience in a General!

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: I learnt this of Monticuli.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: What bustle is that about the door?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Oh Mistress the House is beset: we are all undone.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Not with Thieves, I hope.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, 'tis Dangerfield; fear him not, he dares do nothing: A meer blustring Coward.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Shall we break the Windows?

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: Not yet my valiant Friends; I see Bellamira at her Belcony: I'll proffer Peace; and that refus'd, make War.

sp.speaker: Smoo.
sp.p: O, the difference between Man and Man! I never hear this Master of mine speak, but am the wiser for it.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Answer me thou Punk, thou Cockatrice, thou Man-Leech, that suck'st their Marrow, and their Mony: When I gave thee Isabella, didst not thou promise me two days entirely to my self.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why you over-grown Booby, gelt with muddy Ale, Brandy, and Tobacco; you had 'em and cou'd make no use of 'em.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Next did not you bring your Stallion there under my Roof, talk with him in private, and after steal away to him?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I had some business with him, and found you had none with me, but drinking and making my head-ake.

sp.speaker: Smoo.
sp.p: Oh, Impudence! this to you, that are such a Hercules in Love, and War.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Restore me Isabella or I'll force her from you.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: She restore her! Or you touch her! I shou'd laugh at that.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Are you her Hector? I shall spoil your Mirth with a Brick-bat. Come down; I'll fight thee hand to hand in the head of my Army.

sp.speaker: Smoo
sp.p: No wise General will forsake his advantages, you shan't expose your self so rashly.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Peace you Fool: if he comes, we'l seize him; then offer him in exchange of Prisoners, for Isabella. I here's a stratagem: he shall find I am a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Smoo.
sp.p: The greatest I ever read of.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: I will not venture my self among your Hell-hounds, but I shall find a time.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: You will not deliver Isabella then, by fair means?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Nor by foul neither: She is my Sister, too good to be thy Wise, and shall be no Man's Servant.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: I bought her young of her Friends, in Spain.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: They had no right to Sell her; she is a freeborn English Woman, and I will defend her with my life.

sp.speaker: Smoo.
sp.p: You speak like an honest Gentleman: Bellamira has cheated my Master. Do not make your self a Party; and consequently this great Man your Enemy.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Perswade that Calf he is a Lion if thou canst; I scorn both him, and thee.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Then 'tis no time to talk, salute 'em with a Volley.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Let's give Bellamira a Serenade, as we go by; for old acquaintance sake: she'l take it kindly.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Dangerfield's there: we'l break the Windows, call him Rogue and Rascal, and so go on with our Musick to Thisbe.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I hate these rude Frolicks.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: The house is beset: What's here, Scourers? Brick-bats mounting, and Pispots descending?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: We'l scour 'em for a Company of uncivil. Fellows, thus to disturb Lovers at their innocent Recreations.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Strike up, we have no Drums and Trumpets, but we'l swinge 'em by way of Lute and Violin.

sp.speaker: L. Boys.
sp.p: Fall on: this is our old Master Merryman; we use to light him home drunk three or four times a week.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: If our Soldiers revolt, shift every man for himself: This did Pompey, when over power'd by Julius Caesar, at Pharsalia.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: THis drinking does so muddle one's complexion and take of one's mettle, a man the next day is but the wrong side of himself. I was so doz'd I was an hour about a Billet douz.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: We shou'd look gratefully back upon the past pleasure and not peevishly repine at the present suffering. What think you of a hair of the same Dog?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: That saying has kill'd many an honest fellow, but do you remember we were at Thisbe's?

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Yes, and were let in; but have forgotten most of the rest.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: You are a precious Guardian! You must e'en Marry her your self, you will make her fit for no body else, with your disorderly Frolicks.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: That's it I wou'd be at.
But what said she?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: She told me, she wond'red to see me in that disorder; squeez'd me by the hand, and bad me take more care of my health hereafter.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Now I remember me, she said you look'd lamentably; and that, had you come alone at that time of the night, she shou'd have taken you for a Ghost; that you smelt as if you had been buri'd a Fortnight.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: She may say her Pleasure; but there are as fine Women as she of another mind: I knew when she had no better a Complexion than my self.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: When was that? Had she ever the Green-sickness or the Yellow Jaundies?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: No, before she bought her Paint of the Italian. I look like a Ghost! Why, I am the same man I was twenty Years ago; as vigorous, as Amorous, and I think as taking amongst Men and Women. I had three Maiden-heads brought me last Week by their Parents: I will leap the half Almond with you.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Thou ma'st, well be active, thou hast no more flesh upon thy back, than a Flea, and thy Bones have as much Quick-silver in 'em, as ten Bales of false Dice: They will scarce lie still when thou art dead.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Thou art Picqu'd at Thisbe's concern for me: Well thou art an honest Fellow; we will not dispute about her, tho we Rally one another now and then. I have ten of as fine Women as she upon my hands at this time; she was but my Pis allee: What will you say when you see me Marry'd to one of the best Fortures about the Town?

sp.speaker: Merr
sp.p: I shall not wonder; Women have another Green-sickness in their Souls, that sways 'em to the Trash of Mankind: but here comes Keepwell, his time of Banishment is expir'd, as filthily fine as hands can make him.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Sure Jealousie is the greatest Torment in the World, I have had the dismallest Dreams! Methought I saw Dangerfield Rampant, and Bellamira Couchant all Night long.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: You consented, and can reasonably complain of none but your self.

sp.speaker: Keep
sp.p: I consented she shou'd make a Fool of him, and Cozen him of Isabella, but no farther.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I saw her at Knightsbridge Garden with him; so fine, methought they were the happiest Couple!

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Pox on their happiness.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: It may end in that indeed, they say Dangerfield is not very sound.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Women like wanton Whelps, fawn ever on the next that comes in their way, but, when they see an old acquaintance, they run to him for all that; never be discourag'd.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: At once I hate her, and I love her too; The chief thing I beg'd of her was, that she wou'd not be seen in publique with this Dangerfield: she has no mercy on my Reputation.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: No more than on your Fortune: be wise and take this occasion.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: All this makes for you Merryman: there is no such Soaker as a Lover in affliction.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I had as live drink with a Gib'd Cat: they are alwaies Mewing and Wauling about her Inconstancy, Cruelty, or one silly thing or other.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Dangerfield has a sweet Calech.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: There is no talk of any man now but him; the Bravest, the most Generous, the most accomplish'd Gentleman!

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: You will make Keepwell hang himself.

sp.speaker: Keep
sp.p: I'll fight him, my Courage is wound up, and I will strike him to the heart.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: You'l have an ill time on't; he kills an Humble Bee flying with a single Bullet, rides three manag'd Horses every morning, Fences two hours after, and stinks of Gun Powder like the fifth of November.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Then let him be hang'd, I'll have nothing to do with him.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: 'Tis she is to blame, and not he: If a man Robs my Orchard, I shall blame my Gardiner more than the Thief.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: He has done but what the best Lord in the Land wou'd be proud to do: but I will mawl her, break her China, take down her Hangings, leave her no Plate but the poor Thimble she began the World with.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Spoken like a man of Mettle! and shall we Sup together, and drink till daylight, as we were wont?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Thou art one of Keepwell's evil Counsellors; and if ever he and Bellamira piece again, I shall see thee banish'd his presence for ever.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I will never be sober again, scarce cleanly, take Tobacco and lie in a Bawdy-house.

sp.speaker: Cun:
sp.p: Merryman will Compound for Less.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Half drunk every night, and stark drunk once a week, is very fair.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I'll Rout her Instantly.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: She has a great many Rich Cloaths, let her wear out her Livery at least in your Service.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: That's well thought, let her wear out her Cloaths at least in my Service, as he says.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: You have almost worn out your self in her's: you look worse than he, that begun twenty years before you.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Every man's Constitution will not run out into Fat, 'tis the Commendation of a Capon: a good Cock is alwaies lean as I am.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: A good Coxcomb alwaies thinks well of himself; why thou lean Rascal Deer, thou visible Pox, thou Common shore of Physick, Reproach of Doctors, and Ruine of Apothecari's, who Flux'st away thy Flesh as often as the Adder casts his Skin, and art full as venemous.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I am sure you look like a full Moon or a Fat Bawd swell'd with the Tooth Ach.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: When I walk the Streets, men say there goes an honest well natur'd Fat Fellow to drink a bottle with, and a good Husband I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: A good Cuckold perhaps: but, the Ladies cry foh, there goes a greasie Sot, a Chandlers Shop in the shape of a man, a meer Lump, a Spunge full of Terse: whose mouth stinks worse than the Bung-hole of a Barrel, a Load of manifest impotency, Guts and Garbage for the Bear-Garden.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Thou meer stake to hang Cloaths upon, thou Scarrow, thou piece of Shrivil'd Parchment, thou walking Skelleton that may'st be read upon alive, can'st thou think any Woman so sharp set as to pick thy rotten Bones, which are but the leaving of Pox, Mercury and Consumption?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Nay good Gentlemen, no heat, let us debate this matter calmly; will this Quarrel about Fat and Lean never have an end?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: 'Tis as irreconsilable as that of the Flesh and Spirit; Merryman will never let it rest: I am alwaies on the defensive part.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: You never consider your poor Friend, toss'd as I am between the Billows of Love and Jealousie.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Well-now I have Tormented you sufficiently, it goes against my honest nature to conceal your happiness from you any longer, Dangerfield is an ugly niggardly Rogue, and Bellamiraâ€”

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Was she never abroad with him in Publick.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Nor in Private neither, but once and they fell out; well she loves you most intirely, I cou'd never have thought it.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: She was all in Tears by that time you were on Horse-back: I had the most ado to Comfort her, and, yet I said a great many pretty things to her; and never look'd better in my Life.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I sat with her two hours and our whole discourse was of you, how much she was oblig'd to you, and what a dear man you were.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I ever told you Merryman, you were too hard of belief and that there was such a thing as true Love, and Constancy too.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I confess my error and shall hereafter think you can never do too much for her. I will drink her health in a Bumper as long as I live, for her fidelity to my Friend, and in his absence too.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: If ever you leave her she'l make her self away, that's certain, I have heard her say so a hundred times.

sp.speaker: Keep
sp.p: Nay, I always thought so, and durst never Chide, nor deny any thing; she has such a spirit.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: But here comes Silence, who will tell you more.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: My Mistress wonders you can be so long in Town and not see her.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: What, as a whole hour?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: You wou'd not have been so long out of a Tavern.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I hear she is taken up with Dangerfield.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: He's a Calf, a Blockhead, and she scorns him.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Do you hear this, Merryman? He's a Calf, a Blockhead, and she scorns him.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Did not I tell you as much: and you know I was of another mind?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: My Mistress and Dangerfield, are quite fall'n out: he gave her the pretty Maid she told you of, and came last night with some drunken Bullies, to take her away by force.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I am a witness of that: Merryman and I drove him away, and rais'd the Seige.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: My Mistress will refer all to Merryman.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Now they are in discourse, I will steal away to Mrs Thisbe, and make my excuse for last night's disturbance.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Come Merryman, let's see what Bellamira can say for her self.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I'll follow you instantly.

We were fellow Robbers; I must keep fair with Bellamira or she may get
her own Pardon, Peach, and hang me, besides I have receiv'd her fee; and am bound to plead her cause.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: I am the happiest man! Whom shall I praise first? Thee that laid'st the Design; my self that executed it, or Fortune that gave it success?

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: You have succeeded then?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Beyond expectation.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: It was a bold design.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: And a fortunate one for me: I must have di'd, if I had not enjoy'd her.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I will not trouble your modesty for particulars, but why in this dress still? Do you intend to live and die in your new service?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: I cou'd live and die with my new fellow Servant, I went to Eustace's, thinking to have shifted, but the house was full of Company.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Are you not afraid of being known?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: No, I met Cuningham and twenty of my acquaintance; they star'd at me alittle.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Here he is, and Merryman with him, the vile contriver of Isabella's ruine. Cunningham, I must use your Sword.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: 'Tis at the service of any Gentleman, much more at yours that are my Friend. But against whom?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: You see the man.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What my old acquaintance Merryman, and that young fellow?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: That young fellow is Lionel. When you hear it, you'l say my Quarrel's Just, the Injury not to be pardon'd.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: My dearest Eustace! The Man of all the World I wish'd to meet

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: And Lionel the Man of all the World I am bound to Curse.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Some Villain has abus'd me to my Friend: I'll cut his Throat.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: That Villain is your self.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Villain! Death, I wou'd have shar'd my Fortune, my Reputation, my all, but Isabella, with that Man. and to be thus requited.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: That Name has rouz'd up my Revenge; Draw and prepare for thy defence.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: What means my Friend is he become my Rival?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: That shou'd not make this breach
I'd turn the Boyish Passion out of doors,
And fly to the embraces of my Friend.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Am I reported to have wrong'd you inmy discourse?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: I'd Kick the Liar shou'd tell me so. O that I were so happy as to doubt! You have accus'd your self.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Of an injury so great, to me, and all our Familyâ€”

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: To you? Whose Injuries I count my own, and shou'd alike resent 'em.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Revenge me then upon Lustful Lionel.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Sure you are mad, for what?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Why, for a Rape upon my Sister.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: I know no Sister that you have.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: That's our misfortune, that thou knew'st her not; far hadst thou wrong'd me with thy Will, I cou'd kill thee as men do Wolves and Tigers; but now must pay a cruel Sacrifice to Honour.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: I understand you less and less.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Know then, (for it is just I tell our Quarrel e'r we Fight) that Isabella was my Sister.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: What the young Maid at Bellamira's! 'Tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: By certain Tokens and Circumstances, to me invincible, I know her so.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: You amaze me!

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Lionel, thou wert wrapt in thy Mother's Smock. Thy Isabella, whom thou lov'st of all the World is found the Sister of thy dearest friend. What then remains, but that you Marry her?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: I know his Honour is too nice: nothing remains but that we Fight.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: I love my Isabella above my Life
And all the little niceties of Honor;
And had rather call her mine than be Crown'd King of all the habitable World.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Then we are ti'd in stricter Bonds than ever. Oh my best Lionel!

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Throw not away the Treasure of thy Love, Upon a Soil so Barren:â€” my Fatherâ€”

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: I can easily satisfie all his scruples. She had five Thousand pounds left her by an Uncle: to which I'll add to make her worthy of my dearest Friend.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: I know not how to speak, and yet I must.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Thou found'st her apt and easie to thy Lust: Ha,

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: By all that's good, I hold her Innocent, as violated Temples.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Wert not thou then a sacrilegious Villain?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: It is confess'd.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Now you have confess'd, it is but doing Pennance in a pair of Matrimonial Sheets, and there's an end on't.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: I was to blame, to trifle all this while. Draw.
sp.stage: Fight. Merr. disarms Cunn. and parts the other.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I must have a thrust at thy fat Guts.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Now are thy Skin and Bones, at my Mercy.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: This satisfies my Honour; but my Revenge must find some other time.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: What if I were long since contracted to another, and to be disinherited if I went back.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: You might have told me so? Yet what cou'd that have done?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Perhaps you wou'd not have believ'd me, and it might have look'd like Fear, till we had Fought; but now take the sad truth, and if thou wilt the Life of Lionel: I have been sometime since contracted to Theodosia, the rich Gold-smith's Daughter.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: If that be all, you are as free as you were born. You are all men of Honour, and I'll tell you a secret, I have this Morning privately Marri'd that pretty Creature.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: It is impossible I shou'd be so happy.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: She heard I know not how, that you ravish'd a young Maid, and were in Love elsewhere: I came in the lucky minute, and am now her Husband.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: In the unlucky minute to her. How came she to think of thee?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: She did not; her Maid that Governs her, was formerly a Servant to a Mistress of mine, has often tasted of my Bounty and some other civilities have past between us.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: What cou'd she find to say for thee?

sp.speaker: Cun
sp.p: She told her Mistress, her Father was one of my Tenants, and that I had a thousand a year in Northumberland, to her knowledge.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Thou art a luckie Fellow: the Women will venture Body and Soul to do thee Service any way.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I had miss'd her for all that, but for a Hundred pound I gave a Nonconformist Parson for his good word, Cou'd I have thought the news of my Marriage with Theodosia wou'd have pleas'd you, you shou'd have heard of it sooner.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Joy, such as thou giv'st me now, be ever with thee.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I was half afraid we must have had a Tilt.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Will you be my Advocate to your offended Sister?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: You need none, since your Designs are Honorable.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Let's embrace like Brothers: for the next Priest shall make us so.

div.stage: Enter Bellamira, Silence, Betty, and Keepwell.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Madam, there's the Rogue that has made all this work.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I never lik'd him, he has a slie look; and a Hawks Eie with him.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: 'Twas a mercy any of us scap'd

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Peace you Fools; he is a Gentleman, and may make her Reparation. We are undone ruin'd for ever! Your unfortunate Sister whom I undertook to restore you.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: What of her?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She has been ravish'd, and by that Villain you embrace. But now I am asham d to offer her thus stain'd and sulli'd; but 'twas no fault of mine.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Oh bring her instantly the Roman Lucrece, was not more virtuous; nor an Estate to one in Goal for Debt more welcome, than she to Lionel.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Think what you do; Marry a Servant, my Father will be in Town anon.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: She is the Sister of my dearest Eustace. And above me in Wealth, as in desert. He cannot but approve my Choice.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: When you are Marri'd I'll take my pleasure like an Italian elder Brother, and now my dearest Bellamira, we are safe for one seven years.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: My Father's appetite of Grand-Children I'll undertake to satisfie, if you'l pardon my making bold with your house.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I take it the best way, and charge it all on Love, whose power we most of us have felt. You seem a worthy Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: A poor younger Brother of your Servant Keepwell's.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: How came you to find us here?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We heard that there were Swords drawn; but saw no such matter.

sp.speaker: Smooth
sp.p: There she is; but so hem'd in with friends and acquaintance, we had best let her alone.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: She is a victorious Beauty, I will go and Surrender my self to her.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: Let's make honourable Conditions.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: I will vield to mercy, Hercules did so to Omphale.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: The Example's great.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: What's that thing in Buff.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis Dangerfield: I thought you had known him.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: He looks like a Militia Captain upon a Training day.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: You had best tell him so.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: My heart's too big; I can't endure to speak to him.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Who is that next Merryman?

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: Your Rival Keepwell.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: I can no more endure the sight of a Rival than a fighting Cock can: Hold me, or I shall fly in his Face.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What wou'd that fellow have?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Your Pardon, for my last-night's rudeness; and my Isabella, the pritty Maid I gave you, if you please.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Name her no more: I tell thee she is my Sister a free-born Subject of England.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: If thou dost but name her tho in thy sleep, I'll cut thy Throat: She is my Miscress.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Speak to him, Keepwell: we'l bring you off.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: She is to be my Sister-in-law; and I will flea thee, stuff thy Skin full of Straw, and Set thee in my Cherry-Garden, if thou depart not.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: I am utterly undone; if I find not some way into this Family: the less hope see, the more I love this Bellamira.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: What if I get you receiv'd among 'em, according to your desert?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Command me and mine for ever: I'll give thee fifty Guineas hard Money in hand, and the Sword I twice sav'd the Nation with.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: Retire a little, 'tis not fit you shou'd be by, at your own Commendations. I'll try what I can do; you have been a good Master to me.
I hope all this good Company believes I follow'd this Fool my Master more for my own sake than his?

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: None but himself ever doubted it.

sp.speaker: Smooth
sp.p: I have thought of it seriously, and find you can't do better than to receive this Blunderbus, my Master, into your Family.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: What? A Rival! I will as soon receive a Roaring Lion.

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: Yes, such a one as he is: a Fool, a Blockhead, a Coward, a Knave that ne'r paid.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: For his Cowardice I can answer: he stood to be robb'd, like a Cow to be Milk'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He carri'd me to Supper, and drank himself fast asleep by me.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: If he be such a one, what shou'd Ladies do with him?

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: He loves Play; you may win his Mony, and he has abundance: if he refuse to Play, you may beat him till he will.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I have not heard of a more useful acquaintance, he must not be refus'd:

sp.speaker: Smooth.
sp.p: You need not fear any Woman shou'd like him he has been impotent these seven years: when you are weary of him you may Kick him out of doors.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: He is a man of a thousand: let me intreat for him.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: He shall be admitted, but if he do not prove this Fool, this Coward you speak of, you had better be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Smoo.
sp.p: My life for't. Now, Gentlemen, take me into your Protection, and then Eat, Drink upon, and Laugh at the Fool my Master.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: He deserves it abundantly, for keeping such a Rascal.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Call in Dangerfield, and let him know he is receiv'd without a Negative.

sp.speaker: Smoo.
sp.p: Sir you may come in, the whole Company bids you welcome.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Most welcome, noble Dangerfield!

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I shall be proud of your farther acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: I shall be glad to drink a Gallon of Wine with you at the Rose, we will write you of our Club.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I never knew a Civiller person! I was once abroad with him, and he did not offer me the least rudeness.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Gentlemen if any of you want a Second, I am at your service: And Ladies, if any man speaks ill of you, or Lampoon you, I'll cut his throat: Thou hast charm'd 'em; I thought they wou'd have torn me to pieces e'en now: There are Fifty Guineas I promis'd thee.

sp.speaker: Smoo.
sp.p: I hope Sir, you'l find I have deserv'd 'em; they did not know your worth; but when I inform'd 'em of your good Qualities and Parts, I foresaw they cou'd do no less.

sp.speaker: Dang.
sp.p: Nay, I never came in any place in my life, but when I was well-known I got the Love of Man, Woman, and Child.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now you see what a fellow this Dangerfield was to be Jealous off.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Where there is no Jealousie, there is no Love.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I have had no other Proof of your Love these two months.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Thou shalt have proofs of all kinds.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So you say alwaies

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I have been in the Country, and have brought where with to pay old Scores, and will deal hereafter with ready Mony.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We must have a general Act of Oblivion, now you are one of us no heart burnings hereafter.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: I declare I am in Charity with all the World, but that Fat Thief that laid on me so unmercifully.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He must be comprehended too.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: I cannot in Honour, unless you lay your positive commands:

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You shall never question him. at Law, nor otherwise.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: By these Hilts, I never will then.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Then here are the six Guineas you swore were a hundred, your false Rings, silthy Medals, Table book, and other Pocket-Lumber.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And Merryman and I were the whole Dozen of Robbers, you swore against.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: What, my valiant Bully, you and your man robb'd by two; and one of 'em a Woman!

sp.speaker: Dan
sp.p: As I was going to draw, I heard a voice cry, hold, hold, thy dead doing hand; strike not: it is thy Mistress, Dangerfield.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: You Smoothly, you heard this voice too?

sp.speaker: Smoo.
sp.p: As perfectly as my Master, one might have heard it to Knights-bridge: besides there is something in a man of Honour that keeps him from striking a Lady.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Can you forgive your Lionel?
He never will commit a second Fault.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Not of the same kind, I'll answer for him.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: My heart was your's, when we first met in Spain.
You seiz'd the rest somewhat too rudely here:
But I am your Wife, and now am all obedience.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: How shall I thank Heaven, and Bellamira for her care of thee?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: My former troubles vanish like a Dream,
And am wak'd to perfect happiness
By that voice; Oh, my dearest Brother!

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: I shou'd have known her any where; she is as little alter'd, as 'tis possible.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Husband and Brother I must yield to them; but the third Joy is mine. My Isabella was Lionel the man thou saw'st in Spain? And mad'st that pretty innocent discription of?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: The same: I never lov'd another, and now I never shall.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: How many accidents have met, to make this happy day!
The least of which is half a Miracle.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Does not your mouth water, at these Amorous preparations?

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Not at a greasie bit of a fat Drunkard. I am not ambitious of holding your head in a morning, or carrying you to Hampsted, to get you a stomach to a Drunken Supper.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Your proud heart will come down, when you have fasted from Man a year longer, and been arrested once or twice more.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: I might have gone to Goal for all my worshipful Guardian.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Oh, vanity! vanity! What Knight-Errant, do you think wou'd lay down two Hundred pound for you.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Eustace knows best, he brought the Mony; but whoever he were that sent it, if he have but so much a year, I'll Marry him before any man in England.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: What tho he love Wine, Women, and Tobacco, and were as Fat as I am?

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Yes, with all your faults, and as many more of his own.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.p: Then take her Merryman, she is thine, by her Consession: 'Twas his Mony that did satisfie the debt, and I was but employ'd by him.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: We are all Witnesses; there is no going back.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: She is proof against all Mankind, for I have Courted her these six Months, yet never cou'd obtain the least indecent favour.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Since it must be so, I hope you'l prove as indulgent a Husband, as you were a Guardian.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: My little charge, if thou had'st not taken pity on me I shou'd have kill'd my self with Whoring and Drinking; but now I will beget Sons and Daughters till threescore.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Gentlemen your Company is so good, I had almost forgot I was Marry'd this Morning. Lionel, I hope we shall have no suit in the Prerogative Court, tho I have Marry'd your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Thou art my Redeemer, and hast broken that Knot I shou'd have been troubled to untie. Theodosia was my Father's Choice, (her Bags were contracted to his Acres.) But Isabella's mine.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: These Roguish Fidlers smell a Wedding already; sinceâ€” They are come Let's danceâ€”

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: My Bell. and I will lead a marri'd Life,
Bating the odious Names of Man and Wife;
In Chains of Love alone we will be ty'd,
And every Night I'll use her like a Bride.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Wits, Whore-Masters, Gamesters, Drunkards, Bullies, We in our several wayes are all but Cullies.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: LIke a young Wench that cou'd not well forbear,
And yet is loath her Lewdness shou'd appear.
Our modest Poet wou'd have made away
In private, this mere lâ—mp you see to day.
We bid him lay the Bantling at our door
And for th'event concern himself no more.
Poets of late with humane Sacrifice
Have feasted you like Heathen Deities.
In every Play they serv'd you up a man
Nay some at Parties and whole Factions ran?
After such fare, how flat must Terence taste?
Yet his plain Tales have had the luck to last.
While your fam'd Authors, in their life time wast.
Ye all cry out the art of Writings lost
Yet nicer Judgments in perfection boast.
Strange Stars; malignant to Poetick strains
Yet so productive of Judicious brains.
What if you Judge, as ill as others Write?
And only loath for want of appetite;
No Jew into the Sanhedrim might come
That had no Issue of his own at home.
For barrenness supposes cruelty
No Childless man, might others Children try.
This wholesome Law wou'd save us from the spight
Of all the furious Wits that cannot Write.
And you that do, we shou'd not fear your doom
If you'd Judge here but as you Judge at home;
Now Gallants most of you are so well bred
French has long since chas'd Latin from your head
And Terence yo have forgot or never read.
Faith spare'um both, lest your chance medly Wit
Miss the Translator and the Author hit.
